11.content:
King Ivar (the Bloody)
The aging ruler of Tryzantium. In his younger years Ivar reunited the fracturing Kingdom in a brutal military conquest but these days he spends more time controlling the boisterous fruit of his loins than managing his armies and his martial strength is all but gone, though he still maintains an imposing (if increasingly plump) stature. His hair and beard have turned silver, granting him an almost grandfatherly appearance, though this belies the ruthlessness he is willing to meet out on those that disobey him.
A lecherous old sod, Ivar works tireless to hide his multiple lovers from his wife.

Queen Helena (the Vast)
Ivar's wife and cousin, their marriage was been one of political convenience. Despite the loveless union, Helena has still managed to bear a generous clutch of children. Each birth, combined with her love for extravagant banquets, has increased her girth, so that she now resembles a massive, waddling ball of silk and ermine studded with jewels.
Helena has a fondness for intrigue and spend her time plotting, scheming, and trying to catch the King in his infidelities.

Prince Rilian (the Lost)
The eldest and beloved son of Ivar and Helena, the handsome Rilian vanished during a military campaign in distant lands. It is believed he fell in combat, though in truth he is now prisoner of the queen of Erolus.

Princess Isabella (the Fecund)
Princess Isabella is the eldest daughter. Yet unwed, Ivar is hoping to use her to cement an alliance with the Kingdom of Ordania, though it is vital her virginity is kept intact. This has not been helped by the Church of the Goddess, who recently bestowed upon Isabella a fertility blessing, regarded as a great honour, which has transformed the plain young princess into a broad hipped, big breasted harlot. Her many handsome suitors have Ivar tearing out what remains of his hair.
         - The Bountiful Blessing is a fertility spell designed to turn women into baby factories, making them abundantly fertile, lustful, and capable of inducing lust in any nearby male.

Princess Emma (the Brave)
A strong, courageous woman, Emma has displayed extraordinary skill with sword and bow, and keen martial and political acumen. For a woman. It is Ivar's greatest regret that she were not born a man.

Prince Edward (the Pure)
The fraternal twin of Emma. Ivar's greatest source of frustration, Edward is the sickly, naive successor to the throne. He is pale, delicate, and devoted to the pacificist teachings of the Church. Sensing his weakness, pretenders to the throne are already circling like vultures. Ivar is determined to make a man and a King out of Edward or failing that, kill him and appoint his younger brother King.

Prince Anders
The youngest, Anders is a healthy and adventurous child, always getting into trouble.

Janus Meade the Magician
The court consultant on magic, Janus is a powerful sorcerer fiercely devoted to the Royal Family as only the protection of the King stops his fellow wizards from blasting him out of existence at the first opportunity.

Jiggles the Jester
A rather sad individual, Jiggles is a shapeshifter. He is roughly humanoid with pale, drooping, rubbery flesh. His ability to alter his form has been blocked by enchanted chains.

1111.content:
A meeting had been called in the war room. As the lords and commanders gathered around the table and Warmaster Hogar the Two Eyed began to give his report in his slow, sonorous voice, the King seated himself at the head of the table with his jowls in his hands, staring vacantly over the parchment map laid out before him. There had been a time when he'd loved these meetings, when the little painted clay figurines of Orcs and Elves placed around the map had evoked memories of the glory days of his youth.

But war was a game for younger men now. These days it was his family that weighed heavily on his brow. It was the transformation of his eldest daughter, Isabella, in particular which was keeping him awake at night - quite literally, he had spent last night camped outside her chamber door. Handsome young suitors prowled like wolves in her wake.

As the meeting wore on, many of the Lords struck pipes, and the air of the windowless room was soon thick with whorls of smoke and the deep, sleep-inducing drone of the Warmaster. As usual, the reports of impending catastrophe were without end - the Kingdom's borders were vast, so was its list of enemies.

"The Orc warbands continue their march Southwards. They grow more brazen and gain momentum with each battle, as is their way. They must be broken, and broken hard, or they'll only return stronger. If we can't find a way to stop them - or at least distract or divert their advance - they could very well be at our walls by this time next year. Just something for your consideration... Meanwhile, from Allarmarsh, comes a report of yet another breed of elves - accursed, feral creatures that spew a corrosive substance. Sir Golan was investigating them - alas it cost him much of his skin. The local Elven King assures us that it is an isolated, personal matter that he wishes to deal with himself, though clearly action must be taken if these beasts continue to attack our outlying settlements. Since this is a diplomatic matter, I will only pursue this with the consent of the King of course..."

Hogar paused lengthily for confirmation. One by one, the assembled Lords turned to their King. He was slumped in his seat with his chin on his chest, eyes closed beneath their bushy silver brows, snoring. Hogar's scarred face twisted in annoyance, and he drummed his fingers on the pommel of his sword impatiently. With a snort, Ivar realised he was being watched. He stirred in his seat, blinking bleary eyes at his vassals, who were were watching him in the way they did when they expected him to sign or proclaim something.

"Oh, good. Are we ordering dinner already?" Ivar yawned, stretching and rubbing his hands together eagerly. "I think the stuffed quail today for me-"

"We are not ordering dinner," Warmaster Hogar growled. "We are discussing important matters of state which will decide the future of the Kingdom, whether it survives or falls. It is not asking too much for you to focus on the briefing and not your belly for just a few hours. Or is there something more important than an impending, unstoppable Orc invasion on your mind? Perhaps you'd like to share it with your war council," he muttered acidly, adding, ".. my liege," as an after-thought.

"My apologies." Chastised but amused, the King sat up straighter in his chair. He had a fondness for the old war dog and his chronic inability to mince words even around his King. Perhaps he was the man to ask. None of the others lords had given him a straight answer, soothing him with empty assurances regarding his daughter's chastity and his son's failings.

111111.content:
"An Orc warband of this size is beyond the means of any mortal army to defeat. Leave that one for the colleges," Ivar said dismissively. "Back to these elves, did you say Sir Golan himself had fallen to them? Why, he's one of the finest knights in the land!"

"Not entirely fallen, my friend, at least not yet. His squire rode in with him during the night - what was left of him." He selected a journal from among his notes - the parchment was discoloured and there were holes burnt through the leather binding like swiss cheese. "According to his notes, these cursed elves spew a supremely corrosive bile upon any who come close. It is capable of melting through steel plate as easily as dragon's fire. By his account, these elves melt their victims alive and drink them like a soup. Alas, while studying the monsters, Golan himself was attacked and received a glancing spray across the side of his face. He has been brutally maimed, my Lord. The healing powers of the prieetesshood appears to do little against this foul acid. Even if he survives, he will be blind and deaf, his face melted away, a true horror to behold."

The king's heart sank. Golan had been a true knight, chivalrous, brave and loyal to the crown, perhaps even one of the few men that he might have entrusted to guard the Princess' precious virginity. His adventures were a staple of many a bards' oeuvre and Ivar's chamberlain would always see to leave a copy of Golan's latest excitibg report of daring do on top of the king's desk whenever he detected that His Highness was having a bad day.

"But he's the poster child of the military!" Ivar gasped.

"Not any more, he's not. Not with half his face missing."

"At least he fought gallantly till the end, sire," a young noble smirked. "Nobody could accuse him of losing face."

The king glowered and he rumbled, "Sir Golan is a hero worth ten of any of you. You can lead the force to deal with these elves," he barked at the smirking lordling, whose smile evaporated. "I want these monsters eradicated. Meanwhile somebody find my physician and the court Mage!"

-|-|-|-

A instigator and veteran of many a bloody campaign, Ivar had seen things that would turn the heart of lesser men, limbs hacked and bones splintered. He had a stomach of steel, but the vision of Golan's poor body was near enough to turn his stomach. He gave a groan of despair.

His prized knight looked like a used candle. His burnt melted skin hung in rivulets over raw, red musculature, while his chiselled jaw was exposed white bone. He still moved weakly, calling for his King. Tears welled in his lidless eyes as Ivar hurried to his side.

"It was an honour... to serve... my Lord."

"You're not gone yet, good knight. You've fought worse before and won."

"My... report...."

"We received it. Don't you worry, I'll burn that whole blasted forest to the ground! We'll flush those twisted tree-huggers out together!" A priestess swished into the room with a cloth and a basin filled with sweet-smelling oils to wash and bless the soon-to-be-departed. "Get the hell out of here, you vulture!" Ivar roared. "Where is my physician? Where is my wizard?!"

As if on cue, the man arrived red-faced and gasping, with Janus teleporting in a moment later in a puff of red smoke. Together they poked and pondered over the dying knight.

"Well?! What are our options?!"

The two scholars sucked air through what teeth they had left and shook their grey heads. "Hard to say, my Lord. His body and soul hover on the precipice of death. We may be able to save his mind before his body succumbs. We could cut away the damaged flesh, perhaps save him, but the damage will be extensive and he will certainly never fight again. Or there are treatments that could rebuild his body completely, but the agony may be enough to drive him mad or even sever the last thread anchoring his soul to this mortal plane. You could be left with an empty -albeit healthy- shell."

Ivar was torn. To choose between Golan's mind and body was one of the impossible decisions he hated as a king. Golan's tactical acumen was as powerful and indespensible as his sword arm.

1111111.content:
"How much would be left of him?" Ivar asked grimly.

"If I were to merely cut away the damaged flesh?" The physician bowed his head apologetically. "He would lose his limbs, I fear, eyes, nose, ears. There would be little left of him... but he would... could survive."

Sir Golan's physical might could be replaced, though it would require training ten new knights to make-up for his absence on the battlefield. His tactical acumen and unwavering loyalty however was indispensable. "Do what you have to."

With a nod, the physician pulled from his robes a bundle of dark cloth, unfurling it on the table to expose a dozen sharp blades and other implements. Janus stepped forward to pass his hand over the them, and their blades began to glow with a red-hot intensity. With a steeled expression, the physician took the largest of the knives and began to cut away at the melted, blackened areas of flesh that riddled Golan's body. The patient screamed. The king watched in dismay as more and more lumps of his prized knight were carved away and discarded on the floor.

The physician switched to a bone saw. Ivar turned away as the hideous sound of metal-on-bone filled the chamber, followed by a dull thump as Golan's lower leg hit the floor. The other limbs followed soon afterwards The intense heat of the instruments seemed to cook the meat as fast as it cut, stemming most of the bleeding, though not all of it. The floor was soon slick with it.

Over the course of an hour, Golan was carved up and whittled away like a hallow's eve pumpkin. He had bled more blood than Ivar thought ever possible to be in a man, yet still he clung to life.

"Ubi pus, ibi evacua, Quamish," Janus muttered.

"Do not tell me how to do my job, wizard!" the physician snapped back, wiping the sweat from his brow. "While you were reading your books, I studied the blade. I am the finest surgeon in the land!"

"I fear Golan will be the final judge of your skill tonight," Janus retorted somberly. "The corruption spreads faster than you can cut it out. It eats through him like fire through a log."

Quamish eyes opened wide and he snapped his slick fingers together. "If it is like a fire, then I will smother and snuff it out as one! Fetch me a husk!"

With a nod, Janus vanished in a puff of crimson smoke. A minute later, he returned in similar fashion, this time with what looked to be violently writhing stag skin rug in his hands. He held the stag head by the antlers, while the hollow arms and legs thrashed around, trying to enslave his limbs like the tentacles of an octopus. "Help me get it on to the patient!" Janus yelled. Ivar leaped into action and with their strength combined they were able to remove the parasitic skinsuit's hold on the wizard and force it down on to the knight.

Detecting a potential host, the stag skull split open and sealed itself around Golan's head, while the body wrapped around what remained of his torso. The creature pulsated rhythmically as it settled into place.

"What in heaven's name is that?" Ivar gasped.

"An epidermite," replied Janus, gasping for breath. "Otherwise known as a husks. Or skinsuit. Or the flayed ones. Nasty creatures. Parasites, like leeches, they attach themselves to and replace the skins of their hosts, permanently."

"But they do make effective bandages in a pinch," the physician said. "If we are lucky, the parasite will stem the bleeding and stop the corruption from spread-"

Suddenly the husk let out an ear-piercing shriek, peeling away from Golan and flopping off the table. It slithered into a corner, spasming into a curled up ball, turning black and rotten in moments.

"The corruption kills even the creature!" the physician cried. "Try again!"

Once more, the wizard vanished and returned, this time wrestling with an irridescent, scaled husk in the shape of a young drake. This one was fearsome indeed, even snapping at the king with its empty head of sharp teeth as they wrestled it into position.

"A young, healthy specimen. I have good hopes for this one!" the physician said, though the tremor in his voice gave away his doubt.

As he was drinking a massive red dragon landed beside him.

"I thought I spotted another dragon nearby. Judging by your scent you used to be human," the massive dragon said.

Golan looked at the older red dragon in confusion. "How do you know?"

The red dragon grins at the question. "I used to be human myself. I was turned into a Draconian after my comrades and I killed the former Dragon Queens eggs. At first we were terrified, but over time we became more powerful. We became gods!"

Golan takes a step back. From his military training he had heard that True Dragons fancy themselves as gods. Tryzantium is currently trying to defend themselves from the dragon uprising. However, each captured village has begun to worship their near dragon overlords.

"You're Excallius, the Dragon King" Golan said.

Excallius grinned as Golan slowly backed up towards a nearby tree.

"It's good that you know of me, boy. Since we share a common coincidence maybe you can join my colony. I can teach you all that you need to know about your new species and I have a daughter about your age," Excallius said.

Excallius slowly approached the confused Golan.

"My people enjoy having you around, Sir Golan."

Golan gasped. He didn't think that Excallius would know his name. Golan was at more of a lost than before. He was struggling with his loyalty to his kingdom and his new urge to be worshipped like a deity. Golan...

After that the miraculous healing that induced the drake husk's merging, Golan's survival odds weren't grim anymore. And while it would've been hard to tell how exact for the mage, the physician and the king to tell for sure whenever it was true or not, what they've witnessed was a more than needed proof that the poison had been, at least, culled down enough to be harmless.

Deeming that, at this moment, little more than hoping that things would go well for the transformed human could done, the king dismiss Janus and the physician, only to have the mage transport the patient into a more comfortable room, even if, with that what he's been through, sleeping on the cold stony floor would very be more likable than going through the events of his last travel once more.

Setting up the man within one of the chambers of the castle wasn't an option. Not because of hierarchic nor of value issues, but rather because that the risk of seeing a drake within the building would be hard to believe it is actually done on purpose, and potentially risky for him, given he could be mistaken as a wicked feral beast, a spy or worst.

Instead, they taken him into one of the many housings that the servitors lives in, picking that wasn't inhabited anymore, given that the family that remained there decided to move on after the death of some of their parents.

The home, even if somewhat unkept, since its last inhabitants had left some time, and fairly simply furnished, it would be certainly better than a blood-drenched operation room, especially for the bed, more suited for his well-earned deep slumber.

Eventually, the night falls onto the kingdom, as Golan's sleep gets plagued with dreams, blurred with his memories of his close call against the elves, mixed up with odd images of dragons, causing the man to, inadvertly, roll off his bed, falling flat onto the belly, dazing him, partially from his cycle of sleep being abruptly halted, causing to numb his sensations, as shivers goes through his body as it overreacts, his new condition fighting off the remaining of the foul elf poison.

As the scaly skinsuit had already made Golan into a more draconic human, the changes, while still pretty pronounced, doesn't change him much. Of his digitigrade stance, it gets more pronounced for his legs, as his arms becomes ever-so-slightly more feral, favoring a quadruped stance, without tuning down his human agility.

His neck elongates softly, as his head lose all its human visual features, retaining expressions nonetheless. Small, tubby, and most likely juvenile horns sprouts onto the top and the cheeks of his head, while his tail thickens and lengthens. He, then, proportionally grows bigger and heavier, to roughly twice his previous size, while his frame actually thins out sensibly. And as his muscles actually gets more refined and wiry, his cocks and balls reverts into his body, turning into a clitless draconic slit, completing his gender-changing transforming with a meager pair of B-cup breasts sprouting onto her chest.

After that, and not aware of what just happened, the new adolescent dragoness attempt to step back up, only managing to bump her head onto the ceiling, making her lose her balance, falling right onto the bed and the furniture of the house, causing a noisy havoc.

As such, in a hurry..

But they were ill-fitting, she notices, grabbing the tunic, as they were tailored for her, but when she was still human, leaving her no choice but to make a makeshift cloak of sort, using the blanket she slept in.

Using that moment to remind what happen to herself, Golan had the feeling that her new body wasn't a dream, nor what happen against the elves, but he couldn't why she got to be.. A reptile. And on a lesser extend..

'I found something glittering on the ground.. Out of curiosity i went and tried to grab it, but when i was about to grab it, things went blank and i woke up.. Different. I felt stronger.. They spoke to another man and asked me to take care of you.. At first, i got afraid that you'd eat me or something, but they explain what happened. And given i've e-even met the King.. "What's wrong with me!" thought Ivar, scowling. "One of my bravest and most loyal knights is writhing in pain right here and we, like hounds, are discussing which piece of him we want to save. I won't stand for it!"

Ivar looked back at the two scholars. Still red-faced from fatigue, they were diligently awaiting his order. What will it be? Will his majesty save the body? Or perhaps his soul? Those were the thoughts running through their heads right.

"Don't you know how to save both of them?" Ivar said sternly, causing them to flinch. The two briefly look at each other before shaking their heads.

"I'm afraid to say there is nothing we can do," Janus sighed, drooping his shoulders. But Ivar was a king, and had faced such opponents many of times in the past.

"No, no. I don't think you understood me. You do know how to save him?" Ivar repeated, even more sternly.

"Well..." Janus began, before he shut his mouth as a result of the physician's glare. It didn't go past Ivar.

"Out with it! Unless you want to lose your head, of course," Ivar barked at the two, squinting his eyes. He obviously wasn't going to execute the two, but he had hoped that the threat would provide incentive. After all, they must have heard rumors of his atrocious ruthlessness. And looking at the beads of sweat pouring from their foreheads, they did.

"Well," the physician began anew. "The royal mage knows more about this, but I do know that you can anchor the soul to the body while rebuilding it."

"It's true," Janus continued. "If someone else volunteers to use their internal energy, some in the East call it 'ki', then it's possible to do that. Unfortunately, we don't know what would happen to the person providing it."

"Key?" Ivar repeated.

"No, your majesty, 'ki'," Janus corrected. "It sounds similar, but it's different."

"Alright then, we must fetch someone to provide their key or whatever," Ivar suggested, stroking his chin.

The two once more looked at each other before beginning to interrupt each other.

"That's the problem..."

"There is no one..."

"No one to provide it..."

"Before Golan dies..."

"Unless..."

The two voices united into one for the last sentence.

"Unless your majesty provides it."

"Can't one of you two do it," Ivar suggested, not happy with offering his 'key'.

"I'm afraid not," Janus stated. "I will have to anchor the soul, and Quamish here has to rebuild the body. Quick! Decide before time runs out!"

Ivar quickly interrupted him with a series of laughter. "Qua... Quamish?" He choked on his spit in his laughing fit. "That was your name?"

"Decide," the physician barked, visibly annoyed.

Ivar straightened himself out, calming down. This was a pivotal moment. He didn't want to sacrifice anything of his. However, just one look at Sir Golan... the knight who made him proud. Unknown to his servants, he would stay up during the night, reading his reports while grinning like a little boy. He... he just couldn't lose that. It wasn't even the political acumen that made his decision, but his personal feelings.

"I'll do it," Ivar said, calmly.

The two looked at each other again and nodded.

"Sorry," Janus said. "But this might hurt and..." Ivar wasn't able to hear his last words as the spell flew at him and knocked him out.

-------------------------------------------------

Ivar bolted upright. Looking briefly around him, he noticed his two scholars standing around him and... Sir Golan! He was standing there too! The liquified face was nowhere to be found, and he even looked healthier than prior to embarking on his mission. So he was saved. And Ivar was still alive. He mentally pumped his fist into the air at that thought, as it would be unbecoming of the king to do that in front of servants.

"So, as you can see, we were successful in his recovery," Janus reported, before adding something else in such a whisper that Ivar could only barely hear it. "princess."

"Did I hear that, right?" Ivar began, before noticing the high pitch in his voice. Now that he thought about it, the men around him seemed too tall, even if he was sitting, and his robes were draped all over his body, clearly too big. "No... it can't be!"

"I'm afraid so," Quamish said, before clearing his throat. "It seems that 'his majesty' has gone on a trip, princess."

"Stop calling me princess!" Ivar yapped in his shrill voice. "In addition, what age am I?"

"I apologize," Sir Golan intervened. "But do you remember last month when Princess Isabella began parading and insisting that we call her Prince?"

"I do remember that, my dear knight," Ivar's attitude softened when it came to Golan. "But pray tell me, what does that have to do with anything?"

"Nothing! It's just that... you enacted a law that allowed us only to call royalty according to their appearance and status... so we are forced to call you princess, princess." Golan stated, trying to sound as polite as possible. "And the answer to your question is about 9 years old."

"I'm only 9 years old?" Ivar shouted, losing his composure. "And a girl?!"

"Not to worry, princess," Golan continued. "Your sacrifice has saved my life, and thus, I will now protect yours. I offer that we travel to the Kiccigiorgi Forest, where my residence is, and I shall take care of you with my lovely wife, until a solution to your problem has been found. We shall declare that the King is away on a trip and no one shall suspect a thing."

"I do not suspect that would be wise," Janus rebutted. "We do not know how long it will take to reverse this problem. It could take years for all we know. Or maybe there is none and the King will be forced to grow up naturally. Either way, it's best for the King to take the throne now and declare that there will be solution, rather than later where he would have lost the will of the people. At least now, the people would still accept a little girl sitting on the throne. If he does it later, he will most likely be forced into marriage with a prince from another country. Besides, the Queen is bound to find out, she's extremely shrewd."

Ivar thought about it. Both options were not delightful ones and could lead to severe consequences and him losing his throne. However, he ultimately went with...

The journey to Kiccigiorgi Forest took little more than a week, their steed moving swift as the wind and never tiring due to the arcane encouragement of the wizard, stopping only for them to camp at night. Ivar rode with Golan, enjoying the speed of the enchanted beast and able to sit back against Golan's armoured chest and watch the beautiful wilderness of his kingdom go by. It had been years since he had left the city. Breathing in the clean air, seeing the animals flitting in the lush undergrowth, it all made him feel young again, though being 9-years old again might have been part of that.

It was liberating not having documents to sign, not having his wife looming over his shoulder. Ivar began to daydream, as children are likely to do on a long journey. He had carved out such a vast territory in his life - imagine what he could achieve with a second chance. Why, he could own the entire world. He pictured himself staying in this form, having ten years to plan and consolidate and muster his troops before storming out of his gates as a great and terrifying warrior Queen, all the experience of age married with the energy of youth.

Married. That was the kicker.

Janus galloped ahead in the shape of a mare, giving further encouragement to Golan's mighty stallion. Bandits were common on these roads and it would be unwise to linger, not that Ivar felt anything but safe sheltered in his knight's strong arms.

Golan's estate was relative small, just a few hundred acres of farmland hugged tight against the manor which was a simple squat building. The trees grew large and thick here, and there was a well-defined transition where the estate ended and the shadowed forest began. "Fey woodland," Golan explained. "Make sure not to stray too close, my liege, there are creatures within that would make quick work of a young human girl."

"Like what?" Ivar said, ears shining eagerly for another of the knight's tales.

"Depraved satyrs. Wicked flesh-eating hags. Fexgits and Nixies that will spirit you away to their courts, never to be seen again."

"Have you thought of burning them out?"

Golan chuckled, ruffling the king's hair as if he'd said the darndest thing. "Sometimes. But they don't bother us so long as we don't bother them. For the most part."

The steed trotted to the stables for a much-earned rest. Janus lay in the hay, panting, while halfling servants brushed him down and lathered water down his steaming flanks. A feedbag was being affixed. Ivar jumped down immediately and kicked the tired horse. "Did I give you permission to rest, wizard? You're supposed to be working on a means to fix me so hop to it!"

The wizard gave him a look that could literally curdle milk.

The halfling serfs scurried to receive their lord. They looked happy and well-fed even by the standards of their race, with rosy cheeks and pot-bellies.

As they walked to the manor, Golan said, "A small word of warning before you meet my wife. She is, well.... from around these parts," he said, gesturing to the fey woods in the distance. "She has her fey moods from time to time. It is best to ride them out, like a storm. Ah, here she comes now - oh..."

A woman was marching from the manor towards them. Even from a distance, her dryad blood was plain to see, with skin the colour of bark and hair as green as grass. A loose lavendar dress was draped over a willowy figure, and she had inherited the unworldly grace and beauty that had a tendency to drive men mad. Ivar was surprised to feel nothing. As a man, he had been a sucker for such perfection.

In one hand was a crumpled note, in the other was clutched a dead raven, the life choked out of it. She gestured furiously with that hand, feather's flying. "They told me you were dead!" she roared accusingly.

"Ah. Now, er- I can explain. That message was sent prematurely. I was only, well, mostly dead. I got better!" Golan stammered before his wife.

"I was just about to throw myself from the window of the tallest tower before I saw your horse arrive!" she screamed.

"Zalia, sweetie, don't you think that's a bit of an overeaction" Golan mumbled. "You can't just keep throwing yourself from the tallest tower every time you have a problem. One of these days, the servants wont be there to catch you."

She gave an indignant humph, Turning away from him, she stared down her perfect nose at Ivar...

111121211.content:
The King's voice croaked in his throat as he saw his reflection. Gone was the bulging barrel of a belly draped with thick, crimson silks and ermine. A lavender dress was laced tightly around his slender torso, girdled at the hips to emphasize the abundantly child-bearing properties of his curvaceous silhouette. Beneath his pettycoats, a pair of slim ankles fit into simple, soft leather slippers.

His hand leaped to his breast, seeking out the comforting weight of the thick chains of milthril and gold that had hung around his neck ever since his coronation, familiar companions for over thirty years, yet they were gone, along with the vast wealth and absolute authority they represented. Only a delicate silver chain remained draped across his cleavage.

His breasts were bountiful, threatening to spill over the neckline of the dress at any moment, the constraining material forcing the globes of pale flesh together and upwards, as if presenting them to onlookers for their consideration. As a man, such a sight would have made him cry tears of joy. As a woman, it was all he could do to choke back sobs.

The jowls and the double chin were gone. The features of his new face were strong and beautiful, none of the delicately refined features he so detested in the high born women, with a broad jaw, stern brows, and full lips. His dark hair had grown down to his waist and was tied back, and his crown nestled at a rakish angle upon it. He was relieved to see the crown still there, unchanged, though it was now far too big for his head. It hung down over one ear, threatening to fall.

Her hands sprang for a dagger which no longer existed. "Wizard, what have you done!"

"S-sire, I don't understand.. the Goddess... the blessing... this wasn't supposed to happen!"

"Damn right this wasn't supposed to happen," she roared. "Turn me back right now."

The wizard sputtered weakly, wringing his hands within the sleeves of his robe. "B...but I don't know how! It seems part or even all of the blessing has been forced out of Isabella and into you, but until I can determine exactly what-"

"Just cast the same spell you did on her on me," Ivar interrupted. "That'll remove the... blessing from me and return it to her," Or you, she prayed.

Janus shook his head. "There's no guarantee that would work. If the effect of the first spell were this unpredictable, the second attempt could be catastrophic."

"Just try it. I command you, as your King, cast the spell again."

Janus shook his head, grey faced. "I cannot. It's too dangerous."

It had been a long time since anybody had dared disobey a direct order, and Ivar stepped towards the wizard, fists clenched in rage. Before she could swing at him, she ran into a wall of unyielding muscle as her daughter stepped between them. "Daddy, the wizard is right. We shouldn't rush undoing this with magic if we don't know what will happen. We should..."

1111212112.content:
"We should go see the Sisters, they'll know what to do, father."

Ivar ground her teeth. Aye, they would, they'd probably be able to undo the blessing with a wave of their hand, but what bothered her was what they'd ask for in return.

She'd visited them only recently to demand that Isabella be unblessed. Their price then had been steep - the immediate cancellation of the marriage between Isabella and the Ordanian prince. It was then that Ivar realised the Church hadn't been blessing the union, they'd been trying to sabotage it, terrified of an Ordanian getting a claim to the throne through her daughter. Furious, she'd thrown the offer back in their faces.

The Church wanted nothing more than control over the monarch. Should she arrive at their altar begging for her manhood back, they'd have her by the balls, able to demand any price.

Yet she could hardly afford to wait for Janus to correct his mistake. The King's absence would be swiftly noticed.

Her internal dilemma was rendered moot as Prince George seized her by the arm, pulling her from the wizard's study. As an old warrior of imposing stature, she found herself stunned at the ease with which he dragged her along, her feet slipping on the spiral staircase as she scurried to keep up with him.

The guards watched them closely, Ivar in particular, as they moved through the palace towards the chapel, though the Prince's stature, regal clothing, and imperial air was enough to quiet any suspicion they might have had.

The palace chaplain was a squat, mousy haired woman of middle age dressed in a humble, brown habit. She was busy renewing the candles at the altar, and gave a squeak of surprise at the sight of the Prince.

"P-Prince Rilian, you return!" Yet as they approached her, she shook her head. "My apologies, for a moment there I thought... never mind." Now that she mentioned it, Ivar saw that there was a certain resemblance between Prince George and his lost brother. The same jaw that could break rocks, the same handsome features and cocksure grin. Had she not been his father, she might have made the same mistake.

They stepped up to the altar. The chaplain smiled warmly at Ivar, stretching out her arms as if to embrace her. "Welcome, sister. And what brings you here today, in the company of so handsome a man." Her eyes flicked from the beautiful but evidently lowborn girl before her, to the noble gentleman beside her. She nodded sagely, her hands reaching out to caress Ivar's belly. "Ah, I believe I see. Allow me to sooth your fears; you're not the first expectant young woman I've given a swift, private married. We are not here to judge, that is for the Goddess."

Ivar's face turned a beetroot shade of red. She grabbed handfuls of the chaplain's habit, pulling her close and hissing into her face, "I'm not your sister, I'm not pregnant, and I'm certainly not marrying my daughter. I am your King, bewitched by your foul Goddess to look like some strumpet."

"Y-you're the King?"

"Aye, that's generally what the crown means."

The chaplain's eyes moved upwards (the proportions of the King's new body had a tendency to focus the gaze around the chest). "I... I'll fetch the Archmother," she stammered. Ivar gave her a hard shove of encouragement towards the door, sending her sprawling on her hands and knees.

"You mustn't do that, father," George chided her sternly, as the chaplain scrambled to her feet and scurried away. "This is a place of worship, you can't go manhandling people."

"I'm the King. I can do what I want, where I want," Ivar retorted. As if to demonstrate, she wandered over the stone altar, parking her shapely rear atop the ornately bound holy book that sat on top of it . She glowered at the resplendent chapel in distaste. "A place a worship, hah! A place of meddlers and manipulators."

George folded her arms, an angry pout on his lips. "Well when I'm King I'm going to treat them with more respect."

Ivar guffawed. "When you're King? Evidently I haven't been clear enough. While I have no problem with you sampling the joys of manhood, this state of affairs is entirely temporary. As much as I would love a son and heir of your-" Her eyes darted to the bulge between her daughter's legs. "-impressive stature, I still intend to give you away to the Ordanians. Even if they are a country of boy lovers, they may object to receiving a man for a princess."

"But I like being a man, and I don't want to marry an Ordanian" he sulked, his hands unconsciously sliding down to massage the massive horse cock tenting his trousers, staring openly at his father's swollen breasts. "I don't want to marry anybody. I just want to... fuck. Can't you give them Emma instead?"

"And do what with you?" Ivar scoffed. "I can hardly pull a fully grown son out of thin air and expect the realm to accept him, they'll only assume that you're a bastard. And if I told them the truth, that this-" She gestured to the extent of his masculinity, her eyes wandering over the rippling muscle beneath his tunic. She found herself savouring the sight. "-was the product of arcane interference, the Church would never let you sit the throne. Why else do you think I haven't pumped Edward full of magic? It could make him a man, sure, but an heir has to be free of magic's taint or the church won't crown him."

"Perhaps they'll make an exception for me."

"They won't."

George scowled, sinking into a brooding silence. Ivar had seen that face before, Isabella always wore it when she didn't get her own way, right before she dug her heels in and made life hell for everybody else until they relented. He stalked away from her, glowering angrily at his reflection in the water of the holy font. He looked to be plotting something. She rather hoped the chaplain would return already.

111121211211.content:
Soon the chaplain returned with the Archmother at her heels, and the chapel grew bright and warm with the holy fire that burned about her body, rippling off her skin in golden-red waves. Among the upper hierarchy of the church the wearing of clothing was frowned upon and practically forbidden among those blessed directly by the Goddess herself since to conceal the beauty of the holy female form was an affront against the Goddess' greatest work. As such the Archmother was nude, covered only by the curtains of curly, snow white hair that hung down over her swollen breasts and belly.

Despite her age, Archmother Helena never looked a day older than her mid-thirties and she was always pregnant, a requirement of the title and an effect of the Bountiful Blessing that came part and parcel with it. An Archmother not with child was regarded as ill omen. With her left arm she cradled a baby to her breast, which gurgled and clung to her long tresses. She bounced it gently as she approached the king. A few tongues of holy flame leaped from her skin to lick around Ivar - they didn't burn, merely enveloped her in a warm hug.

She smiled, all dimples and rosy cheeks. That's disconcerting, thought Ivar. She had dealt with this woman many times but not once been greeted with a smile, only suspicion and contempt. The church rarely had fondness for the king, for any king in fact, regarding them as violent patriarchal thugs, a blunt tool through which to extend their influence at best.

"What seems to be the problem, dearies?" Helena cooed. "The chaplain says you don't want a wedding, is that true?" She looked the masculinised Isabella up and down, licking her lips. "You're definitely sure about that? It only takes a minute. Oh, I do love a good wedding."

"For the last time. No. Weddings," Ivar growled, leaping down from the altar. "I am-"

"She-" Isabella cut in loudly, "-is nobody of importance. I am Prince Rillian, heir to the throne, returned to take my place as king after my father's disappearance." He sank into a deep bow. "I swear my life to the service of the church, to upholds its tenets as long as I reign."

Ivar choked and sputtered. "You little liar. You are no Prince Rillian, my daughter, nor will you ever be king. You're a spoilt, greedy girl and I'll have you over my knee when this is done!"

"And I shall have your tongue cut out for speaking in such a way, maidservant," Isabella retorted, positioning himself between the Archmother and Ivar, who found herself backing away from the imposing figure, her backside pressed against the chapel's altar. She felt panic mixed with a strange parental pride. She had always hoped to sire an heir with the balls to seize the throne. She never expected it to be Isabella.

Ivar pulled the crown from atop her dark curls, waving it triumphantly. "Does a maidservant wear a crown, Archmother?"

"Then you are a maidservant and a thief!" Isabelle lunged to grab it. Ivar was shocked at the fluidity with which her new body dodged away from her daughter's grasp, though the sudden movement left her fecund form jiggling. "I caught her raiding the vaults, Archmother!"

"This is the doing of my mage, Archmother! Speak with Janus."

"See how she cavorts with wizards, Archmother!"

"Enough from the pair of you!" the Archmother's sharp tongue cut through them. "You two had best stop squabbling right now, or neither of you will get to be king." The baby had begun to cry. She cooed and bounced the baby gently until its cries subsided before turning to Isabella. "Isabella, I'm disappointed. You should know better than to try to try to lie to me. As your father said, you are no Prince Rillian. A convincing likeness, yes, enough to fool the common man no doubt, but you forget that I was there when his mother delivered him into this world, and I watched him grow, as I did you. He is as familiar to me as any of my own children." Isabella hung her head and mumbled an apology. Ivar shrank back as the withering gaze of the Archmother fell on her. She found herself being chided like a child caught playing in the mud. "As for you, Ivar, how many times have I told you to stop associating with that wizard, to stop toying with unsanctioned magic that you neither understand nor control? But not only do you not listen, this time I find you trying to pervert Her very design. Your arrogance knows no bounds."

Ivar ground her teeth. "Save the sermon for Sunday, Archmother. Can you fix me or not?"

"I can fix your problem," stated the Archmother, "but I won't."

"W-what?" squeaked Ivar, before hurriedly closing her mouth in embarrassment, surprised at her high pitch, biting her tongue in the process. "Ow!" Ivar whined as she brought her hand up to her chin while trying to soothe her tongue. "Archmother! Why won't perform such a simple task at hand? This kingdom is missing its king! What will they do without me? Surely you jest!"

The Archmother cackled loudly. Realizing that this action caused the baby to cry again, the Archmother hurried to bounce the baby once again to calm the little child down, before turning to Ivar. "I have heard various rumors about you, Ivar. Many rumors. I'll be frank with you. I have always had this sense of... nausea when dealing with you, and it looks like the rumors were true."

Ivar spat as she stated, whilst stomping her right foot, "Rumors are simply that! They are nothing but the deceit and falsehoods of my enemies, jealousy that rampant all over the kingdom in regards to my glorious deeds." Ivar smirked, as she remembered carrying out capital punishment to all those who spoke ill of her, or rather him, when she was king. 'Wait,' she mentally thought, 'I still am king. This form will not prevent me from getting what I want from the Archmother!'

The Archmother scornfully looked at Ivar as she once again had to proceed to calm the little one down. Once finished, she turned back to Ivar before stating, "Don't interrupt me. I haven't even finished my part yet. I don't mind your executions or your political rivalries or your personal statehood. Those matters are not of importance to the church. What does disturb me is your treatment of women!"

"What?" Ivar yelped, not expecting this change in pace. She was expecting the Archmother to disdain her for her corrupt policies or the execution of her rivals. Not this. What did she even do to women to deserve such disrespect?

"But Archmother," protested Ivar, "I haven't done anything that would result in poor treatment!"

Archmother shook her head before replying, "No, your current predicament is because of that. I have heard that you were preventing poor Isabella here from fornication with others. You should know that is a sin in front of the church. A woman's stomach must always be filled with life. I have also heard that you have been neglecting the Queen in that regard as well. So unless you learn to treat women with proper respect, you shall stay in this form."

Ivar's jaw nearly dropped as she heard Isabella giggling to her side, which was rather strange as Isabella was a man now. Quickly snapping her head and giving him a sharp look, Ivar turned to the Archmother while stuttering, "B-but Archmother, I-I promise to reform. I-I will do my best if you just give me a chance."

The Archmother, while cradling the baby, seemed to ponder for a moment before replying, "No, I cannot trust you to change your ways until you show me that you can. As soon as you deliver three children, I promise to return you to your former form."

Ivar nearly fell as her legs buckled. She could only stare at the Archmother as she heard Isabella laughing hysterically to her side. She didn't even have the strength to chastise her as she could only utter, "B-but what about the kingdom? And Isabella's marriage?"

The Archmother smiled, "Surely you have not left heirs behind for nothing, have you? Prince Edward shall do the trick. In fact, maybe you should even retire and leave him the kingdom whole. As for the marriage with the King of Ordania, I'm sure that he hasn't actually seen the princess, has he?"

Ivar paled at the suggestion. He knew what the woman was implying. But he couldn't bring himself to actually believe that the Archmother said it. She certainly wasn't going to walk up to the future King like some harlot and devote herself to him!

The Archmother continued, "Fortunately, only a part of the Goddess' blessing inhabits you - a part of it is still left in Isabella here. So you should be able to retain your innocence until the marriage... I think."

Ivar growled as he stated, "Fine! I'll resolve this problem by myself!"

Ivar stomped out of the church with Isabella following suit, as the wails of a crying baby filled the room behind. Marching through the street, she didn't notice how observers sneaking peeks at her wonderful bosom and her childbearing hips. Leaning in, Isabella whispered, "Father, shouldn't we take the carriage?"

"Hmph," Ivar snorted as she continued onward, "Pay them no heed, they won't recognize us anyways."

As soon as the two got back to the royal palace, Isabella asked him cautiously, "So father, what are you going to do now?"

Ivar only had a moment's hesitation before replying...

Ivar felt her passions getting the better of her. She raced forward to correct the stupid woman. 'He was the King... He couldn't be pregnant!!" The very idea was offensive.

But even as he approached her, she seemed to slow down. As if she were moving through treacle. The king's eyes darted about, even she was affected.

This was a powerful magic, she saw that even the flames of the candle were flickering more and more slowly before stopping. She saw that the chaplain was frozen in place. Turning to see if Prince George was seeing the same thing, she saw that he too was still as a statue. One hand indecorously adjusting himself.

Uncertainly he reached out and touched his newest son... but nothing happened. He remained in the same pose, with a warmth in his skin he felt sure that was a good sign... and she dearly needed a good sign right now.

He didn't want to admit it, but he was terrified. What would he do if this never ended. He turned to run from the little chapel, his eye spotting a feather hanging motionless in the air. Perhaps.... just perhaps Janus hadn't been affected by ... by whatever this was....

She just wished that there was a little less motion from her own body, as her cleavage shifted when she turned.

Marching up the aisle to the exit, her stomping transformed into a strut. It wasn't a conscious choice, it just came naturally.

"I haven't dismissed you, girl." a voice boomed behind the king.

A girlish squeak came from her as she whirled back around. She wasn't prepared for what she saw there.

Hanging in the air above the altar was the glowing outline of a female figure. As King Ivar watched, she fell to her knees. The outline filled in, with tones and shades. However, the face remained stubbornly blank. The light was the brightest there, as the King squinted, her arm raised uselessly.

"Goddess..." he stammered uncertainly.

"You have offended my with your rejection of my blessing. Princess Isabella would have been a good consort, moderating her husband in the difficult times ahead."

Ivar made to start talking, but her reasons felt like excuses under the harsh light of the Goddess. Her lips moved silently, before she gave up.

"But such blessings should not be lightly removed. I have changed your history, Ivar." Her voice was firm daring her to even challenge a Goddess for the limits of her power.

"And I have changed, George's too. The palace chaplain's unexpected wisdom has merit."

Ivar shuddered, he really didn't fancy the idea of pregnancy as her punishment. "Please...." she started, overcoming her terror.

"Foolish woman... a child only comes from love."

The King fell silent again, whatever her punishment, she breathed a sigh of relief.

"You suit being on your knees, girl. Besides, it is appropriate in to show respect to royalty."

She bit her tongue.

"Truly Prince Rilian has returned... and just in time too. The kingdom was in danger with the absence of the King."

"What!!!" her bluster undermined by coming in such whiny tones.

She felt a weight vanish from her head, as the crown turned to smoke and vanished, leaving behind only long cascades of raven hair. It didn't stay missing for long. Before Ivar's eyes it reformed above Rilian's head, settling onto his lush manly locks.

"Now... Ivana..." she pronounced the King's new name clearly. "You have to perform an act of penance, to regain your status.... and throne."

The Goddess cast her arms forward, and a golden glow spread outwards from her fingers, encircling and cocooning the kneeling figure.

You shall lose your status as royalty and be cast out to spend the rest of your days as a commoner. Heed my warning and do not fight against this." Time unfroze around Ivana as her long lost son and now King Rilian gave her and Prince George a warm embrace. "Brother! Sister! I came back the second I heard of father's passing. I went to the church first thing in order to go through the coronation so that our country still has a king and stays strong."

Some of them were from the overwhelming feeling of terror at what the Goddess had just declared, but mixed in were tears of joy at seeing her son (well, now brother) again. George simply looked even more confused, "What?" Apparently the Goddess had not spoken to him about the situation. Ivana broke up the silence by saying, "You should go see your mother Rilian. She will be very pleased to see you."

"I shall go now. We've got a very important week ahead of us."

"Yes we do." Ivana said and grabbed Georges arm to lead him out of the church. Rilian snapped his fingers. His hood was replaced with godly garments. Ivar noted that not only did Rilian get taller, but that he had put on a lot of muscle and was somewhat fatter too.

"As for Edward I will train him, but as of today you're no longer king. You did tell me after all that I would be crowned upon my return," Rilian said.

Ivar was about to protest, but he couldn't refute Rilian. He did tell Rilian that he would do so. If he broke his promise, especially since Rilian is now a god, he would be smited on the spot or worse.

"He's right," Ivar said. "Man or god his claims are true. We must prepare for a coronation."

Rilian grinned as the other nobles began talking among themselves. "My coronation will be held tomorrow. This council is dismissed."

Ivar sighed. Out of all things he was regretting making that promise to Rilian. Now seeing that his eldest son is a god all of his extramarital affairs would be made public. He was certain that Rilian would ruin his plans.

Before Ivar could leave the council Rilian placed a strong hand on his shoulder.

"Father, you do know that I'll have to banish you for your crimes against Tryzantium," Rilian said. "So I'll give you a choice. You can either face banishment or drink this."

A mysterious glowing potion appears in Rilian's hand. "Drink this and all will be forgiven as long as you swear not to partake in your wicked deeds. Do we have a deal?"

1112.content:
With a weary flourish, you stamp your royal seal on the last of the decrees and toss it on the stack of parchment that sits in the Out Tray, for your chancellor to deal with later. It has been a productive day of administration. You have earned a break.

Despite being alone in your study, you twist in your seat to scan the room. Your ears strain to hear any minute noise. Even here, in your private sanctum, you feel that your wife or her spies are somehow watching. There have been times when you swear you hear creaking of floorboards from within the walls, or that the eyes upon the tapestry are turning to follow you around the room.

But today you hear or see nothing that could suggest eavesdroppers. You slip a simple wooden locket from your pocket and flick it open. Inside is coiled a lock of golden hair. Gently you lift it out, twisting the beautiful strands over your old war-callused fingers, smelling the sweet fragrance. Your lecherous mind conjures the image of the amorous young scullery maid when which the lock came, skin smooth as milk, a body like a ripe peach. You had met only briefly. There had been time only for a few stolen kisses and hastily uttered sweet nothings, but it left you wanting more. Today you will get more. That will be your reward for being such a responsible ruler.

Pushing back your chair and striding across the room, you throw open the door.

"Going somewhere, my Lord?"

The guard outside the door stands to attention. You don't recognise him. He is fresh-faced and eager. Without a word, you stomp past. The guards footsteps keep pace with your own. "Why are you following me? What are you doing?" you snap.

He gives a smile with the faintest hint of a sneer. "Guarding you, my Lord. I am a guard after all. Wherever you go, it is my duty to escort you there."

"Not today. This is a private matter."

"Private matter or not, sire, orders are orders. It is for your own safety after all."

"'Orders'? 'Orders'?! I am king! My command overides your 'orders', as you should damn well know! How long have you worked here?!"

"Oh, quite a while, sire! At least two weeks!" he beams.

The man is on kingsguard duty after two weeks! Then you notice it- the silver ankh of the Goddess hanging on a chain around his neck - and you understand. This man is a spy. You've long suspected your wife of sneaking her own agents into the castle guard. Their eyes are everywhere.

It would be easy enough to dismiss this guard, yet to do so would only confirm your wife's suspicions that you were hiding something.

Muttering, you turn around and storm back to your office, slamming the doors behind you. The guard returns on the other side of the door. Somehow you must give this young lad the slip.

111211.content:
You slam the door behind and immediately begin to search. But as you scan the room, you see something moving out of the corner of your eye. Something which really shouldn't be moving. Your gaze is drawn to the large oil painting that hangs above the fireplace.

The painting had been given as a present by your wife some months ago, and was one of those that gives you an uneasy feeling, as if the eyes are always following you around the room. Once you had even removed it from the wall to check that there weren't eye holes drilled into the wall behind but had eventually been forced to concede that your old mind was playing tricks.

It depicts - or rather would normally depict - the nude figure of a woman astride a white horse, being made to ride through the streets of the city with only her long hair to shield her modesty, as the crowds heckled and leered at her. It was a scene from the old story of Lord Godiva who, as the story went, had once been a cruel man who taxed his domain harshly, that was until the day that he was tricked and transformed by his wife into the form of a young woman and made to take a walk of shame before his subjects.

https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/c...

Today however, the painted figure of Godiva is not sat inanimate upon her horse. She is moving. You watch, stunned, as she tosses a cigarette down onto the cobbled street and scrambles to pull herself back into the saddle, but without stirrups she loses her grip and lands hard on her backside. She glances back over her shoulder and out of the painting, her eyes going wide in terror to see you storming across the room towards the fireplace. "Shit!" she cries and tries to run, only to hit the edge of the painting as if colliding with an invisible wall. She dives beneath the horse's red and gold coat, out of sight.

"What sorcery is this!" you bellow, tearing the painting from the wall. "Spies everywhere, hiding in plain sight! Even the walls have ears. Come out from there, you nasty little eavesdropper, there's no hiding now."

The painted figure continues to cower. You give the painting a violent shake and she is thrown back into view, only to scurry back into hiding. "What are you and who put you up to this? It was my wife, wasn't it!" The painted Godiva is now cursing loudly as you hurl her from side to side, knocking her against the confines of the frame. "Well if you wont speak, it's on the fire for you. I'll look forward to watching you burn."

And you shove it on the fireplace. The flames lick at the canvass, and the woman screams as growing black spots begin to eat through her world. "Not like this! I'll talk. I'll talk!."

You drop the smouldering painting on the hearth. She sits huddled in one unburnt corner, scowling.

"Okay, you were right," she grumbles. "Queen Helena put me in here. She had me repainted to look like this bitch. Said it'd just be for a few days. That she'd let me out when I found out who you were fooling around with." She glares at you. "You were supposed to hang me in the bedroom, damn it, where the action is. Not the study. I don't even know how long I've been in here..."

You think back. It had been your birthday that you received the gift. "Seven months."

"Seven months of sitting on a horse... No wonder my ass is sore!"

"How much have you told her?"

"Nothing, I swear. I've got nothing to tell her. Every day I just see you come in here and stamp parchmentwork. She barely even checks in on me anymore. Hell, it's been weeks since I saw her last, she probably forgot about me for all I know. Look, I don't even want to work for her anymore. I just want to go home to my wife and kids."

You chuckle. "'Wife', eh? So who were you before you came to hang over my fireplace?"

The painted woman gives a slight bow of her head. "Agent Veeto, at you service."

"Well, Veeto..."

11131.content:
It was a fine, frosty morning in the dead of winter and Ivar stood in the courtyard, eager to depart. A light snow had fallen during the night, which would make the stags all the easier to track. Not to mention he loved the sight of the sprays of crimson against the sheets of white. Why, he would probably be able to follow them just on the clouds of steam from their mouths, he thought, as his breath hung about him in the cold air.

Dangling from around his fingers were four horse shoes. "The day is young and I wish to depart! Where is my horse? She is late!" Ivar growled aloud to himself. "A horse! A horse, my kingdom for- ah, here we are!"

The captain of the guard pushed open the gate of the courtyard - behind him trudged several dozen men, some in guard uniform, others still wearing pajamas and grumbling as though recently kicked from their bunks. With a harsh bark, the captain ordered them to stand in a line, which they did, sluggishly.

As he stepped up to the king, a young man followed him, staggering a little as though inebriated.

"Apologies for the delay, sire. Your, ah, horse was having a late one night. She's a little worse for wear."

Ivar clucked his tongue, his eyes flashing angrily at the younger guardsman. "Was she now? Drinking a little too deeply from the trough, was she?! This displeases me!" He approached the guard, stretching his eyelids to examine the bloodshot eyes. He could smell the ale on the boy's breath. "Just because my horse is drunk does not mean she shall avoid the crop! In fact I will see fit to whip your flanks all the harder for it!" He turned to the guard captain. "And where is Epona's other half?"

"Ah... I do not know, my lord. I could not find her. It is possible she was also out drinking last night. However, any of these others cadets will surely suffice. I have assembled the hardiest and fastest."

"I will be the judge of whether they will suffice or not," Ivar said quietly before indicating to the captain to strip the men. Somewhat confused but nonetheless awed in the presence of their king, the men quickly doffed their armour, civvies or pajamas.

"About face!" Ivar barked. The men spun on their heels, some a little drunkenly.

Ivar paced up and down the row of men, examining them, as their naked bodies shivered and steamed in the cold. Occasionally he would stop to grip the calves of one, or the thighs of another, or to squeeze the buttocks of a particularly fine specimen.

"Excellent musculature on this one!" he declared aloud eventually, as both of his hands squeezed the iron-hard buttocks of guardsman #32. "Wonderfully long legs! Healthy skin tone! She's a beauty alright! She'll make a fine addition to my stable."

Stepping away, Ivar set the horseshoes on the cobblestones. Epona #1 had done this before and knew exactly what to do. He stepped forward quickly to stand with his bare feet on the front horseshoes.

"Well, what are you waiting for?" Ivar barked at the one he had just selected, pointing at the read horseshoes. Confused, the man stepped into them. "Grab her waist, girl!" the king bellowed impatiently.

The young man at the rear nervously reached forward and gripped the waist of the man in front. Immediately the shoes began to glow brightly. The young man nearly jumped out of his skin but, alas, he was unable to jump out of the horseshoes, which now appeared to be glued to his feet. Furthermore, his hands were glued to the man in front. He began to tug at his fingers, but they had begun to fuse with the skin below. The flesh of his hands began to liquify and pour into the other man's back.

"Epona certainly sounds spirited today, sire," the captain of the guard ventured nervously, as the screams of the man at the back filled the courtyard. Ivar shot him a sharp look. The man's arms had now fused almost entirely with the back of the other man, dragging his face ever closer. His screams were cut short as his head turned to fleshy goo, and fused with the spine in front.

Thick, red hair was sprouting all along the length of this fused entity, while the human musculature swelled into that of a horse. As the spell went on, they resembled less and less two men, and more and more a single horse, a statuesque mare of noble proportions. The front man's skull cracked loudly as his face was pulled into the long snout, a huge horsey tongue spilling out of the mouth before it had a chance to resize.

It had been an excellent solution to the problem of training the King's horses, who he tended to grow bored of after a few uses. Instead of training the horses, they could simply make them out of the excess guardsman sitting around the castle. Ivar had requested Janus to handle it, and the stable was now fully stocked with all manner of enchanted horse-shoes, saddles, bits, and skinsuits.

Finally Epona was complete. She staggered a little, her hooves clopping on the cobbles. Her rear half didn't quite seem to be playing ball, moving out of synch with her front as though trying to pull herself away, her tail swishing in agitation. It wasn't unusual for the rear to take a while to adapt - the loss of sight meant they have to soon learn to surrender control to the front half. It was nothing that a few sharp strikes from a crop wouldn't sort out.

The stableboys rushed forward with saddle and bridle, and began to make her ready. Ivar...

11133.content:
On this day, Ivar was hunting in the royal forest. He and his hunting party were hunting as usual. So far Ivar had encountered nothing but squirrels. For a typical day of hunting Ivar hasn't been having any luck.

"Dammit! The forest is awfully quiet for today. After searching for a few hours we ought to have found something by now!"

"Sire, you spent a majority of the morning trying to kill your son, Edward. Your daughter Emma then threatened to slit your throat the next time you laid a hand on her younger twin. On top of that you had to order some of the female guards you hired to take Isabelle to her room so she wouldn't assault some merchant. Do I need to mention that Anders almost lit the stable on fire." the huntsman with Ivar said.

"I get your point, Joshua. If you speak to me like that again I will personally rip out your tongue."

"Understood sire."

"Good. Hopefully we can find something.The sooner we can get a few deer or something the better."

After walking for a few moments Ivar saw some bushes rustle.

"Finally! Now to catch whatever lurks behind those bushes!"

Before Ivar could ready his bow, whatever was hiding in the bushes decided to attack. The assailant was some sort of weird creature. Before Ivar could get a glance at it the creature quickly bites Ivar's hand. The creature had moved with such amazing speed that Ivar couldn't defend himself. Just as fast the creature had made itself known it darted off towards the west. The most disturbing thing though that the creature had an evil cackle.

"What the hell was that thing! I had never seen anything like it! Looks like we got a pest to... Awgh!"

Ivar starts doubling over in pain. He then passes out.

"Darn it! The king's been poisoned!" One huntsman said.

"I don't think that's the case, Jerome. It looks like he has some sort of disease."

"Easy for you to say, Josh. The king looks like he's in some sort of delirium. Maybe if he dies one of us could become king. All one of us would have to do is marry one of his daughters."

"Are you nuts! Ivar would pluck out our eyes, chop off our crotches, or have Janus turn us into animals. Just last week Simon was turned into a cat."

"You have a point, yet I just wish he would of sent a search party for Rilian. He might have united the kingdom, but his corruption is slowly destroying the very kingdom that he unified."

Before Joshua could answer another huntsman pierces Jerome through the chest with his sword.

"How dare you speak of such treason. Die you foul mouthed gossip. No one will miss you."

"Gerald! Why did you kill him?"

"I was just doing my job. A job that you should have done. Instead you entertained the words of a traitor. That is also unforgivable. However, I decided to spare your life. I cannot carry King Ivar back to the wizard on my own. His belongings and kingly figure are too much for one man to carry. If it was just him I should be fine. Now grab his gear and meet me in the medical bay in the castle.

Dang, Gerald didn't really have to do that. I would of talked some common sense into Jerome, but alas. The king is now ill with a disease from a creature that no one has seen before. Hopefully we can cure the king. With Rilian still missing none of Ivar's male heirs being acceptable substitutes. Isabelle is too much of a pervert to rule, but Emma could pull it off. But such thoughts are not to be spoken aloud.

Gerald and Joshua take Ivar back to the castle. They immediately have Janus give medical aid. It wasn't until three hours later.

"He's waking up! Sire, do you remember what the creature looked like?"

Ivar mumbles a few incoherent words. "I... I think I may remember. The creature was quite large. It was definitely an anthro. I believe the sun was setting when it attacked."

"Sire, what you described is none other than a werebeast. Werebeasts are cursed to transform each night to transform into a beast. However, the transformation isn't always stable. Was it a werewolf or some other werebeast? Tell me sire." Janus said as he held his wand up to his king.

"You threaten to kill me without proving that I was attacked by a werewolf or whatever that thing was. Yet somehow he seemed familiar. I can't put my finger on it, but whoever that beast was I'm going to kill him! I don't even care if he's a trusted ally or possibly my lost son Rilian. I will have that monster's head on a silver platter." Ivar growled.

"Sorry milord. It's just that we have to take precautions. If we can't cure you than we will have no choice, but to kill you if you turn into a werewolf or any other kind of werebeast. If you don't become a lycanthrope we'll have to study you to see what affects that creature's bite has on you."

Ivar ponders it over for a moment. "Fine, but let me know if you find something on that creature."

"Will do milord."

Meanwhile, on the outskirts of the city a man and woman meet under the moonlight.

"Did you do the job, darling?" The woman asked.

"I did as you instructed me. Now when can I go free?"

"Not yet my love. Remember that you are my prisoner until you accept my hand in holy matrimony. Also we must see that Ivar suffers. Soon he'll look like what he is on the inside... a beast beyond reason."

"Very well, he must suffer for what he did to me. He must pay for his treason!"

The woman steps into the full ray of the moon's light. The woman is a tall red head. Her red hair blows in the breeze. Her blue eyes give off a cold yet peaceful glimmer. The man's identity remains obscurred by the hood over his head. His attire is that of a noble or knight. The pair gazes off into the night as their plan unfolds.

1114.content:
In the privacy of his chambers, King Ivar sat in the chair before the fireplace, his arms folded over his large belly. Staring with furrowed brow into the dying embers of the fire, he dreamed of glories past. He remembered fondly the forging of his Empire, the wicked villains and archenemies he had vanquished, and the loyal friendships he had forged along the way. His knights... The men and women who had fought side by side with him with the vigor, strength and hope of youth.

Many of those friends were gone now - retired, infirm or dead. Not even glorious deaths either, for some of them. Kremir Dualforce had tripped over a spellbook and tumbled from the window of his tower. Edirix the Teethtaker had pulled her back out at the age of 45 attempting to lift that vast two-handed greataxe of hers - bedridden until infection took her.

Ivar stared at the pudgy sausage-like fingers of his hands. He missed the days when they had been caloused, strong and bloody. Now they were discoloured only by the splotches of ink from signing so many royal decrees!

The kingdom that he had reforged was stable and secure, yet it seemed a hollow victory now. Peace had robbed him of his purpose. Oh, how he wanted to feel that youthful vigor again. To be an adventurer! To journey and fight and carouse and fuck whoever, whenever, wherever he pleased!

"This castle is suffocating me," he grumbled to the empty room. "I have to get out, I have to be fr-"

As he spoke, his eyes fell on the portrait of his wife hanging over the fire. There was one in every room. She was always there, watching him...

She would not approve. To live the life he wanted, he would have to do it in secret.

11144.content:
At that moment, there came a musical rapping upon the door. Ivar's heart soared. "Enter!" he bellowed excitedly.

With a gait closer to a jig than a walk, Addoros Gladdenhart the Bard swept into the room. The diminished embers of the fireplace burst into life as he did so, burning a multitude of colours, sending rainbow light across the walls. The light played off the gaudy silks adorning the bard, his attire and presence making the king's finery look drab in comparison.

A small holden harp hung upon the bard's hip by a leather strap. At times he would pluck a string or two. Something about the chords he chose must have been special, Ivar thought, as just the slightest sound evoked emotions of joy, or sorrow, or heroism within his heart.

Addoros performed a deep, acrobatic bow, the feathers of his cap jiggling merrily as he did so. "Addoros Gladdenhart, at your service," he said, his voice a melody. "And you must be?" he added with a wry wink.

Ivar chuckled. "You know very well who I am."

Addoros grinned perfect, pearly teeth. Several women in the neighboring rooms swooned, though they knew not why. "King Ivar, I know who you are. Yet I do not know who you might be."

111443.content:
"King Ivar, I know who you are. Yet I do not know who you might be."

King Ivar sat up straighter in his chair. "You speak of... The Tales?"

"I do indeed," said Addoros.

From his jerkin, he produced five scrolls sealed with a curious, glittering wax. The light of the room seemed to grow dimmer until it only the scrolls seemed to be illuminated. A hush fell. Even the eyes of the portrait of the Queen seemed to strain closer.

Addoros whispered, though his voice filled the room. "The bardic colleges tell wondrous tales of the heroes of yore. It is our stock in trade. Of course, all know that not anybody has a story - only a chosen few rise to be heroes. But what most people don't know is that some stories do not have any body to tell them. Tales just waiting to be told. Tales without a hero...yet. Locked within each of these scrolls is the destiny of a hero. Some great." He gave a slight shrug. "Some not so great perhaps," he added in smallprint, his whisper no longer seeming to echo and boom on the last part.

"Where on Tamoria do you find such things?" Ivar gasped in wonder, his fingers itching to tear open all five of the scrolls at once.

"Our secrets are our own, even to you, King. Some say that they are prophecies that have existed too long and become tired of waiting. Others say that the Bardic Colleges track down promising heroes-and-villains-to-be and pay them large sums of gold to give up their destinies so that we can sell them on for massive profits to rich folk who want a lark. Who can truly say?"

Addoros watched as the King's fingers reached out, gliding over each scroll, unsure which to chose. "Each of these will make me a hero again?"

"Hero? Villain? They will give you a destiny, a part to play in the theater of the gods. Perhaps your part will be grand, perhaps it will be more of a ... side character in the tale. Either way, you will play the part until the destiny is fulfilled, upon which you will become King Ivar once again."

The king's hand withdrew a little. "But if I can't fulfill the destiny asked of me...?"

"What would an adventure be without a little risk?" said the bard with a reassuring strum of his harp.

Unable to restrain himself anymore, Ivar snatched up one of the scrolls, tearing open the wax seal. A flicker of light burst from the scroll and sank into his chest as he unfurled the parchment.

The text was small, ornate and spidery. An entire hero's tale written in tiny, dense script upon the scrap of parchment. With his aging eyes, it was hard to make out the writing but the name at the top of the scroll was legible enough...
