1114431.content:
“Palseya... Maidenlight?” Ivar’s blank look of confusion slowly turned into a rakish grin. “Ah, a good name for a ladies man; cavorting around taverns, wooing women. A fine destiny!”

“Actually, Palseya is Erolusian for ‘beautiful flower,’ I believe.” Addoros helpfully added, a small smile on his face. And her gods would brook no sleeping around, I do believe. Or drinking. Oh, and mixed fabrics are a big no-no.”

Ivars smile slid off his face. “Did you say he—ughluph” He collapsed forward in pain, clutching his stomach. The legs that he was kneeling upon began to shift, liver spots fading as skin became pale and smooth.

Through the tears of pain clouding his eyes, Ivar could spy the face of the bard peering at him. “My liege, I must say, I didn’t expect you to take the Tale so poorly. Though come to think of it, it was quite painful for the original Palseya herself — I suppose losing and gaining the favor of the gods is a painful affair.”

“You… bastard…” choked Ivar. But the insult sounded feeble, its bite dulled by his new musically pitched voice. His gaze dropped down to his tingling hands; the pudgy, wrinkled digits were tapering down into long, smooth fingers — the kind that would be delicately crossed in a lady’s lap, or demurely extended for a noble to kiss.

Addoros opened his mouth in mock shock. “But, my king, I’ve given you exactly what you wished for! A hero’s destiny and life — and all the trials and tribulations that come with it. Being a virgin priestess is hard work after all. Palseya couldn’t take it herself; she actually sought out one of our members, begging to be released from her duty. Last time we saw her, she was off to some bordello with her newfound gold. The poor dear probably hadn’t been touched since the day she was born.” He sniffled dramatically, dabbing at his eye with a silken handkerchief.

Ivar merely grunted in response, the mounting pressure in his body taking the larger part of his attention. The wizened muscles in his arms and legs dwindled to nothing, leaving only the accumulated fat from years of sedentary rule. But that too changed in the coming seconds, his limbs dissolving into soft little things, unsuited for slaying even the most feeble monster.

A surprised ‘Oh!’ and the sound of tearing paper drew Ivar’s gaze back to Addoros. The bard was holding a scrap of glittery paper. The rest of the was dancing around the room in miniature scraps, their backs as white as the locks dropping into Ivar’s eyes. The rest of the hair bunched up inside the king’s crown, which hung loosely on his diminished skull.

“I’ll just help you out there.” the bard chirped, lifting the crown up and off of Ivar’s head, sending a cascade of snowy hair down his back. With a quick flourish, the crown disappeared from his hands. “Payment for services rendered.”

“That cwown is a welic of the—” Ivar stopped short to spare himself some dignity — and to let his lips swell to the same girth. “That crown is the Royal Family’s, bard,“ he eventually spat. “It is not for commoners to toy with!”

“I know that, my dear Palseya,” Addoros smirked. “I just thought to lessen the burden on your sainted head. Yours is a great calling, after all — I wasn’t even allowed to read your Tale.” He flounced a hand at the flurry of paper dancing around the room.

“Don’t… call me… that…!” Ivar gasped, pushing himself to his feet with a heroic effort; his new feet weren’t suited to carrying his substantial paunch. “You will change me back… or I will — Ahhnn~!”

A warbling moan escaped his lips as the pressure crescendoed to a climax of pleasure, not even noticing the great force constricting his every inch. Ivar’s belly shrank along with his ‘kingly rod’, leaving behind the smooth core and unplucked flower of a model priestess. Shoulders pulled inwards and shrank, loosening his robes. At the same time, his hips burgeoned outwards into pelvis-defining curves, the alluring shape serving alongside the rush of feminine fat to his thighs and rear to cinch his pantaloons to the brink of tearing.

The pleasure and changes concluded as a pair of breasts asserted themselves on his chest. Ivar was left half-crouched on the floor, sweat beading on every inch of his new pale skin and hot breath escaping his mouth in aggravatingly high coos.

“It’s good to see that everything is in order, my lady.” Addoros’ voice rang out, laden with false courtesy. “I was half-worried the Tale may not take, but it seems it has agreed quite well with you.” The scraps of paper framing his face began to curl and blacken, burning in an otherwise-impalpable fire.

“I will hunt you down to the ends of any land, you thrice-damned pissant, flay turn your flesh into a slurry unless you turn me back! Right. NOW!”

The bard covered the center of his wide grin with a single finger. “My my, so angry. But you shouldn’t speak that way at that volume in the chambers of the king; I’ve heard that he’s missing!”

Ivar’s face purpled with rage as his clothes writhed and shifted: His pants split in two at the thigh, the cloth of the legs unwrapping themselves into lookalike ribbons. They coiled itself around his feet like twin snakes, forming footwraps that anchored themselves securely in the cushiony flesh of his thighs. The remaining fabric paled into a bright shade of white, curling itself around his pelvis and rear, sending a chill through the uncovered portion of his upper legs.

His robes underwent a similar metamorphosis, the hem of the royal attire creeping up ribs whilst the cloth in the front and back of the garment remained static. Ivar let out an undignified squeal as his jerkin vanished, exposing the curve of his breasts for all to see. Frustratingly, the twin curtains narrowed in width, baring more of his sweat-slick skin to the cold air. It was cold comfort when the wide circle of leather that formerly served as a belt softened into satin and bound the two drapes together.

“Now you dress me like a whore?!” Ivar shrilled, balking when his chest threatened to wobble out of its precarious position.

“Quite the opposite, my dear.” Addoros wagged a didactic finger at the crouched king. “Those are the traveling raiments of an Erolusian priestess. They protect the poor dears from being accosted by brigands — save those with a death wish. Not many thieves want to bring the wrath of the gods upon their heads, after all. I like to call them look-but-don’t-touch togs.”

His chuckle was low and loud, and all the more infuriating to Ivar. He tried to stand up; to beat the bard with infirm arms, to call the guards to rip him apart, to do anything, but all strength had deserted him. “I’ll have you hanged…” was the only thing he could mutter out as he collapsed to the floor, eyes flickering between open and closed.

“My my, someone looks tired. Don’t worry, dear, I’ll tell the guards that the king is sleeping — give you…” Ivar could see the tall figure astride the hearth produce, check, and return an object from its belt in one smooth motion. Gravity pulled down his eyes once again “...four or so hours to sashay out of here after your little catnap. You’d probably have the run of the castle: No one’d suspect the pure little priestess of wrongdoing, after all!”

Ivar lightly flinched as the bard bent over his prone form. Gods, he just felt… vulnerable. But there was no attack against his unprotected body; instead, a low whisper echoed in his ear: “I’d call them normally — dramatic escapes are just grand for an opening chapter — but I imagine the deck is stacked against you already. Good luck with the Tale, dear!”

The (former) king could hear, but not see, the familiar creak and slam of the chamber doors through closed eyes. With a legendary effort he opened his eyes; just in time to spy a white scrap of paper fluttering down in front of his eyes. The short snippet, ‘________’ was all he knew as he tumbled into the warm embrace of sleep.

11144311.content:
Ivar lay, twitching and moaning softly, lost in a troubling dream. In the dream, he was trying desperately to chase down a slip of parchment upon which was written 'King Ivar'. Every time he grew close, a gust of wind would whip it further away, accompanied by a single high chord. His body betrayed him, growing weaker and wearier.

Just as his fingers closed around the paper, it was torn away once more, landing lightly in the outstretched hand of a peacock-coloured bard, the Royal Crown atop his head.

Ivar awoke with a start in his chambers, dimly illuminated by the late evening light. The fire was dead. He had slept for hours, as the bard had predicted, though, from his snowy hair to his dainty toes, his body still trembled and ached with the fatigue of being forced into the shape of a young maiden.

Pained mewls emerging from his lips with every laboured movement, Ivar dragged himself towards the mirror. He needed not to confirm the truth (a single glance downwards would have confirmed everything, nor was it possible to ignore the feel of the carpet beneath his heavy breasts), but he hoped there might be some aspect of the man he had been remaining.

For a long moment, he stared into the face of the young Priestess, recognising nothing. His eyes drifted over her form. She was young, only an acolyte most likely, and beautiful - yet he felt no stirring of arousal within him at the sight of the nubile, vulnerable maiden before him. Even more than the change, that troubled him. Not only was his manhood gone, but his most basic, basest male urge along with it.

Have I become a maiden, not just in body but in mind too? he shuddered, turning away from the reflection.

The bard had implied he should escape, lest he himself be implicated in his own disappearance! Could he reason his way out of this? The Church and the Crown had always been in opposition to each other - what would his own Lords make of him, if a woman of the cloth was found at the scene of his vanishing? They would hang him for regicide no doubt. What would the clergy make of him, if they discovered one of their own in such a state within the King's chambers? They would have him stripped and whipped through the streets as a harlot.

In the mahogany chest of drawers beside the bed, there was always kept a Draught of Vigor for when the King needed a little materia medica mid-conquest. He dragged himself there, and slid open the lowest drawer.

At the sight of his own undergarments, Ivar's stomach turned, bile rising to his throat. The piles of crumpled off-white britches, pantaloons, and unwashed codpieces filled him with a new, strange revulsion. Though they had been his own mere hours ago, now they seemed unclean things. Soiled things undeserving of touching his skin.

Pushing aside those feelings, he plunged his hand into the garments. His stomach knotted in disgust, as if he was elbow-deep in worms, but his fingers closed around the glass phial. He ripped his arm out as fast as he could, shaking with exertion and repulsion.

Many of the gods had Virgins with a capital V among their clergy, girls chosen before puberty to be sworn to nothing but their faith. They were made to swear vows of lifelong celibacy, trained and groomed to reject all matters of the flesh. Their purity and innocence was sacred - any sign of them straying from such a path would be punished severely until their chastity became second nature to them.

Had Palseya Maidenlight been one of these sacred Virgins? Had her church trained such a rejection of matters of the flesh into her that she was physically nauseated by physical proximity to such things? Was that training so ingrained that it was now in him too? A disturbing thought indeed... Ivar took a glance at the drawer of underwear, pressing a dainty hand to his full lips as the bile rose once again.

Well if the gods wished him to remain a virgin maiden, on that they could agree at least! Ivar certainly had no intention of giving his unplucked flower to anyone.

The Draught fizzed once the cork was popped. He downed the liquid within the phial and slumped back against the bed. After a few moments, he felt energy re-enter his chest and flow out to his limbs. Though still weak, he could stand without his knees knocking together with exhaustion.

Ivar winced as he stood up, the pain of exhaustion still dormant into his bones. His lungs still ached, morphing his breaths into soft coos. He brushed a few locks of sweat-damp hair from his forehead, only to have them fall down again.

“Damn it.” he muttered, gradually shifting his weight from the bedpost to his legs.

Walking came easier than he expected, but it contained unexpected challenges. His stride had to be short, lest he wanted his pelvis to be exposed to the cold air. But besides his burgeoning sense of modesty, the small steps forced his soft thighs to rub against one another with every step. This wasn’t particularly striking in and of itself— the king had been living in that reality for fifteen-odd years — but it unveiled another distressing reality to the king:

He was, simply put, weak. Even after years of sedentary life on the throne, his strength hadn’t quite deserted him. He could heft the greatsword used for knighting ceremonies — albeit with both arms — and pull back a longbow (On a good day).

Now, his thin arms were soft and untoned, and his chest and rear oscillated whenever he made a movement, not a trace muscle to hold them firm. It’s not even the mark of a glutton,’ he desponded. ‘Just the body of a girl who never worked a day in her life.

Ivar set his face and shook his head to clear his thoughts. Twenty minutes in this form and he was already concerned with his body's shape! But there was a point in considering it; he would not be able to rely on Palseya’s strength to overcome any challenges. Only cold steel could help with that.

He cast a forlorn gaze at the aged battleax hanging a few feet away from him. It would be nice to heft it once again, but even dislodging from the wall was daunting, and discreetly hiding it would be impossible. A more subtle approach was necessary.

Ivar approached the writing desk that had occupied so many of his recent years. Sheets of parchment were scattered over its surface, some blank, and some lined with prewritten decrees. He took a seat at the bare wooden chair, grimacing at the ‘cushion’ that accompanied him. His eyes narrowed as they surveyed the desk, trying to recall the location of a secret latch somewhere.

But as he peered over his secondary seat of governance, a seed of anxiety took root in his stomach. What would Tryzantium be without Ivar the Bloody on the throne? The web of alliances and coalitions that he had spent the better part of thirty years delicately arranging could all fall apart. The Colleges could attempt to usurp the place of the Church; the encroachment of foreign nations, or, Gods forbid, elves.

His careful balancing act, torn asunder in a matter of weeks. He would not, could not let that happen.

Ivar whipped a blank sheet of parchment out of a sheaf with practiced ease, simultaneously dipping a quill in a nearby inkwell. His Council fought like a flock of squabbling hens, but they could be trusted to govern. For a short while.

The quill cut dark lines into the parchment. ‘For the eyes of the Council. Rule as I would — I shall only be gone a month.’ Ivar allowed himself a small smile of satisfaction. The instructions were clear enough, but the enigmatic nature of the message would keep them on their toes. Maybe.

His smile faded and his brow furrowed as he considered the issue of his family, however. Helena might be rudderless without a husband to scrutinize, but her love for banquets would lead her to maintain the status quo. Isabella would be kept locked up if the Council had any sense. Emma’s time would be monopolized by her martial training — an unusual habit for a woman, but it kept her occupied. Anders’ tutor kept him on a tight leash, skipping his lessons would be the most trouble he could get into.

All that was left was… Edward. The quill pen trembled in Ivar’s grip, fueled by rage and anticipation. Any lesson he had tried to impart to the boy simply didn’t take. He spent most of his time dodging the responsibilities of manhood and princedom, and the rest was spent in the library or chapel. The boy needed a firm hand to guide him or, failing that, to put him down.

The king’s mind teemed with possibilities. Maybe Edward the Pure could benefit from a baptism by fire: leading a force against the Northern Orcs would toughen him up. Or maybe a few years in the decadent courts of Erolus would pound some guile into the boy. Ivar laughed — a sweet, tinkling thing that concealed intricate plans of cruelty.

1114431125.content:
The shadow of the quill loomed over the parchment, ready to scribe the fate of Edward. But the quill hung in the air, still as the hand that was holding it. Ivar’s focus was far away from his chambers, his castle, or even Tryzantium: rather, it was in his mind.

~~~


Ivar stood astride a great rocky hill, the landscape around him torn asunder by a battle more fierce than any he had waged. He was a young man again; a great warrior in his prime, clad in the finest armor. His arms rippled as one hefted a grand battleax with ease, the other a massive greatshield. But no companions stood beside him, and no army was beside him.

He was alone.

Ivar tensed every muscle in his body. An attack was coming; he could feel it. And come it did, but not in the form of steel, but as a hail of words, sharp as any arrow.

“You cruel, cruel man!” the voices howled. “How could you think of doing that to your own son!”

Ivar glanced the blows off his shield with practiced ease. “I am a KING!” he bellowed. “If he is to be one, he will follow in my footsteps!” His voice was laden with implication; the alternative would be unpleasant.

A second volley screamed towards him: “You dig tunnels into the walls of your castle to avoid the gaze of your wife! Is that the life you want for the boy?”

Ivar smirked; that was even easier to deflect. “A life spent sampling the lovely fruits a kingdom has to offer?” He lifted his arms to the grey skies, reveling in the lack of nauseation he experienced. “Worth a thousand compromises!”

Silence permeated the landscape for a long while. Was it over? Ivar took a tentative step off of his perch before halting suddenly. Another attack was coming; he could sense it.

But as he squinted in the direction his instincts had portended, he could not help but smirk. It was a pitiful thing; hardly larger than a child’s fist. He didn’t even bother using his shield: What harm could it do?

“Don’t you feel bad about this?” hit Ivar square in the chest.

The king’s body spun through the air at the impact, eventually scraping to a halt in front of a large boulder, armor torn off like tissue paper. Ivar was left breathless, involuntarily lifting a hand to his chest to assess the wound. But he touched no blood, nor wound, nor muscled chest.

Instead, his hand made contact with the same sagging chest he had lived with for the past twenty years. His hand desperately scrabbled to his other arm, his legs, his face; only to discover familiar jowls and loose skin. All his muscle was packed underneath years of accumulated bulk — again!

“See?” asked a soft voice. Ivar whipped his head around, desperately searching its source, before the voice spoke once again, echoing in his skull. “You do feel bad.”

The words struck Ivar once again, but this strike did not send the king flying. Instead, a familiar force started to press down on his body. Feverish ‘no’s spilled from the king’s lips, pitch rising with every syllable.

In a few moments, it was over: Ivar’s body was, once again, small, weak, and abundantly feminine.

Ivar curled his pale hands into tiny fists. Was this some great divine joke!? And, this voice, this impudent, inaccurate, insistent voice — “Stop talking!” Ivar punctuated his squeal with an impertinent stomp, no longer caring about his wobbling protuberances or propriety or anything else. His plump bottom lip wobbled for a few pregnant seconds before he continued. “And you’re wrong!”

“No,” the voice gently chided, seeming more familiar by the second. “You are wrong.”

A wave of pure emotion swept over Ivar, half-submerging his rational mind in pure guilt. Certainly, he was within his rights to educate Edward, but it was simply brutish, the way he went about it. No, wait that wasn’t right. No, it was.

Ivar gripped his head, which felt like it was about to burst at the seams. “Wait,” he managed to whimper out. “Stop.”

The voice continued on, not heeding his pleas. “Edward is so brave, isn’t he?”

Absolutely not. Well, he hasn’t demonstrated that in combat, but there was a certain nobility in how he persisted.

“And he’s quite intelligent too!” The voice continued to gush.

Not in any way that counts. There was no denying that; the boy did spend an awful lot of time in the library, after all.

“And, well, he’s quite dashing~!” The voice of Palseya cooed embarrassedly.

NO.

Ivar broke free of his vision with a guttural roar, and forced the quill to paper, carving the words 'DO WITH EDWARD AS YOU WILL.' into the parchment.

A strange cocktail of satisfaction and guilt bubbled inside Ivar. He flicked wild eyes from wall to wall. He swore he could hear girlish voices echoing off them. He clutched his head again; he could not be sure if his thoughts were his own in here. This room, this castle, all of it was too much.

He snatched a dull paper-knife from the table and stowed it in one of his billowing sleeves — there was no time for secret weapon stashes. Bits of ash swirled around his legs as he strode quickly to the door and opened it with a trembling hand, making only the barest sweep for patrolling guards before he scampered into the twilit hall.

111443113.content:
Ivar took a few experimental steps, half expecting to fall over once more. But his legs, though unsteady, did not give out. A few paces followed, then a few more, and more, ‘till he was quite sure he could walk unsupported.

The quiet pride at his accomplishment was quickly smothered by seething rage. He was expected to play the part of this… this frail girl! His fists balled as his lips curled into a snarl, he would certainly—

A flash of white motion drew his attention to the mirror. The view that greeted him was humbling; a delicate girl with her hands bent into impuissant fists, the snarl on her face more impudent than intimidating. It brought to mind memories of spats with his daughter before she was ‘blessed’; an image that belied the hexed king it contained.

Ivar pushed down the great anger bubbling inside of him. In this form, he could not afford to charge forward now; lest he ended up manacled, whipped, or worse. Escape came first, then action could be taken.

The king strode to the wall adjacent to his bed, probing the stones with thin fingers. In order to hide his many dalliances from the Queen, a chamber had been constructed to disguise the ‘participants’. It had been constructed secretly, by the advice of a prodigal genius in the fields of architecture and enchantment. His reward was hasty conscription into the siegecraft division of the army. Even now, his letters and missives were secretly screened by agents of the crown; if they contained the slightest hint of catching on, he was to be disposed of quickly and discreetly.

These distant memories passed through Ivar’s head as he finally depressed a stone in the wall, sending part of it quietly grinding open. Yet, instead of satisfaction, a heavy emotion weighted his chest. Ivar wrinkled his nose in confusion as he identified the sensation… as guilt? No, it can’t be, he reasoned. I’ve done no wrong.

Even so, the sensation persisted, even as a hallway much larger than its containing wall it was lit meter by meter by enchanted torches.

The chamber, he had been assured by its creator, was the first and only of its kind. Its stated purpose was to be a bastion for the king if his castle were to come under attack, which was true, in a more metaphorical sense. The left wall was lined with ‘armor’, in the form of outfits meant to both disguise one’s egress and titillate the king — primarily the latter. The right wall was, appropriately, lined with ‘weapons’, in the form of bindings and the latest ‘in sexual paraphernalia; both magical and mundane.

It was to the left wall that Ivar firmly affixed his attention; the stains and musky scent of sex on the right sending convulsions through his slight frame. But though they had less of a… physiological reaction, the clothes he saw were more taxing mentally.

Ivar had vastly overestimated the number of acceptable disguises in the chamber. Amongst the unacceptable candidates was a scant two pieces of sheer fabric that served as a ‘dancer’s outfit. Its owner came from a troupe that had come to celebrate Edward’s 13th. The wan prince had taken his leave after a mere three hours of celebration, citing ‘My duties’ as a pale excuse. Normally, the king would have chastised the boy for his poor show of manhood, but the dancing girls were holding his attention.

A few winks, nods, and silent glances later and the girl and the king were off to his chambers, the girl coming 20 minutes after with a maid outfit over her scandalous garb. And, well, now… Ivar took an appraising glance downwards. Gods, he could fill it out and then some!

He hurriedly moved on, arms crossed protectively around his chest. The light patter of his feet echoed off the walls as he passed nightclothes made of translucent cloth, ornate gowns that would take an hour to put on, the mere rags of a beggar…

Another piece of clothing caught his attention. A black hood crested the top of an equally black traveler’s cloak that swept the ground, even from its high pin. The corners of the king’s mouth started to raise for the first time since his transfiguration. It certainly wouldn’t do for the castle, but it would be excellent garb for—

THWUMP

The king would’ve liked to meet the noise behind him with a barbaric yawp, weapon in hand, and steel in his eyes. Alas, he was simply not in the right state of body nor mind for such heroics.

Instead, he let out a piercing squeal and scampered behind the cloak. His breath came fast and sharp for a few long moments before he gathered his courage to peek at… an ornately carved phallus.

Bile hastened to his throat as his hands shook with anger. Was this unseen hand of fate to strip him of all dignity, and turn him into some hysterical maiden? His breath hitched as his vision blurred — Gods, was he going to cry?

The emotional exhaustion of maintaining his composure was too much for the king’s tired form; he collapsed to his knees with an undignified grunt. As if to mock him, his chest wobbled and shifted with the jolt, only pushing him closer to the precipice of hysterics.

The small portion of Ivar’s brain that wasn’t tied up in this emotional tug-of-war was desperately searching for some means of assuagement. But there were precious few of his old habits to fall back on: no spirits were nearby to imbibe, no prisoners or peasants were available to torment, and any carnal means of satisfaction were certainly infeasible.

Ivar could not tell whether it was his new body or his spirit that laced his fingers together. He could not tell whether his own will or someone else’s shifted his gaze towards the ceiling. But the words “Help me,” whispered in a trembling falsetto stemmed from no-one but himself.

The whisper echoed off of the rock walls, and it was as if a small sun had lit itself in the King’s chest. A vast wave of calm suffused Ivar from head to toe, smothering distress underneath a great weight of placidity. Even the residue of exhaustion that rested in his bones was expelled, replaced with quiet energy.

Ivar passed a hand through his silver hair, the embers of anxiety still slightly trembling his fingers slightly. Had that been… him? In his times of adventure, he had seen the truly faithful shift great objects with a mere prayer, or bring people back from the brink of death. Did the Gods still hold Palseya in their favor, despite his own lack of faith?

He quickly struggled to his feet, hurriedly brushing the dust off of his clothes. It simply did not bear thinking about: he would not be doing anything like that again!

But his hands remained clasped in front of his chest as he apprehensively made his way to the back of the chamber; to more sensible disguises.

In his adventuring days, Ivar had always resorted to strength, size or swords first to resolve conflicts like this, with smarts being a distant consideration. With three vast humans bearing down on him, he struggled to adapt to the situation. Admittedly he had only been a gnome for 12 seconds.

With a roll of his eyes, Addoros addressed the guards, those his gaze was focused on the king. "Careful with this one chaps. Gnomes are a slippery lot. Why, they can even fall from great heights unharmed," he said wit ha theatrical wink.

Ivar didn't need telling twice. With a burst of speed, he darted out from underneath the descending chamberpot towards the window. He jumped for the window latch, and was delighted to find his gnomish body spring into the air like a rubber ball. His deft fingers snagged the latch and...

The latch refused to budge. Dangling from the latch, he tried waggling his body back and forth, putting his full body weight into shifting the rusty mechanism. But his body weight wasn't what it once was. The window remained resolutely shut.

With a 'thwang', a crossbow bolt skimmed past Ivar's head, blowing the window out in an explosion of shards. With a cheeky 'thank you' to the guard reloading the crossbow, Ivar launched himself out into the open air, the castle moat glinting hundreds of feet below...

111443243.content:
The gnome-king’s hair whipped about him, the dull shade of pink made bright by the afternoon sun. The loud groans and venomous curses of guards slithered out of the broken window, one particularly loud voice asserting that he could definitely hit that gnome bitch with his second shot — she had just cursed his first shot with her wicked magic.

Three thoughts entered and exited Ivar’s head in short order:

The first was a blend of amusement and contempt — with the way that crossbow had been maintained, that guard would have to be lucky to hit a giant at ten paces. Halfwit.

The second thought was mostly comprised of confusion with no small amount of concern. How did he know that? A menagerie of explanations and rationalizations paraded through his head before the third thought cleared them right out.

Perhaps ‘thought’ was too strong a word. A more fitting term would be ‘the sudden realization of impending death’. The small trees and brackish tributaries lining the moat were getting awful big, after all.

Tears streamed from Ivar’s eyes, some from the wind, some from fear. Listening to the bard was a snap decision; the open air outside the castle walls seemed a sight better than the leer of his castle guards, but he had neglected to consider the ground.

Had the king known more about his new gnomish physiology, he would have had less reason for panic; the worst injury a gnome could suffer from a fall of this height would be a dislocated shoulder or two. But the most contact he had with the greenish race was a brief smile and a toss of a coin to a small, excitable minstrel — not the most informative of exchanges.

So it was with newly deft hands that Ivar rifled through his pouch, fingers brushing across tools and bottles with desperate speed. The ground fast approached as he managed to stick his entire arm in the pack — it must have had a Holding charm placed on it.

Desperate for options, his hand involuntarily grasped itself around some kind of metal pole; the first non-phial or tool he’d laid hands upon. He pulled the object from the bag with three desperate yanks and was almost immediately flooded with dismay.

It was a parasol — a familiar sight in his court, come summertime. This particular one had a black fabric covering its whalebone frame, with a curve in the base of its handle like a shepherd’s crook. It was longer than his body, the tip of the device even stretching above the length of his now-vertical ponytail. Gods, this was the reprieve he got?

Still, it was better than nothing. Marginally. Ivar scrabbled for a latch or lever to release the mechanism — maybe it could slow his descent somewhat. But as his hands traveled up and down the shaft of the parasol, a button was involuntarily depressed …

The tip of the parasol — that, by the grace of providence, was facing downwards — lit up with a Crimson magic circle, and almost immediately started to belch great gouts of fire. His fear for his life compounded with the reflexive avoidance of heat and overwhelmed poor Ivar’s sense of dignity; leaving him to squeal at a ludicrously high pitch whilst clinging to the gadget for dear life. Gnome and umbrella rocketed into the sky, passing the chamber window handily.

The guards watched from said window, mouths wide open with shock; all ideas of crossbow shots and crown theft purged from their minds. Addoros too, watched the gnome rocket through the sky, a single raised eyebrow the only thing betraying his surprise. “Well, it’s certainly a fascinating opening.” he chirped, ink-dipped quill already scribbling the first verse of a balld.

High above the castle’s spires, Ivar had managed to pull himself astride the odd device with a heroic effort. A side effect of his new riding posture was a correction in his path of flight: from vertical to horizontal — something that he was immensely thankful for.

But there was the matter of height to consider. Merely looking down sent a lurch through the king’s tiny stomach. That had to be fixed. With nervous resolution, he gripped the hook-like end of the shaft and shifted it the tiniest amount clockwise, with an equally tiny lean right.

The parasol, in accord, shifted right. The anxious frown slowly cleared from Ivar’s face; this might be easier than he had thought.

The king continued his experimental process in the air above his castle, turns and dips gradually increasing in depth and risk. This culminated in a barrel-roll that left him shrieking with delight, strands of pink hair stuck to the edges of his manic smile. Ivar swiped a small hand to dislodge the tresses and gazed down at his castle. It seemed so small. The people seemed so small.

An incredibly ill-advised plan hatched and matured inside the king’s little green skull.

He sloped his makeshift steed towards the same window he had exited. He pulled the handle to the left and performed large, lazy circles, all the while craning his tiny neck to get a good view inside. A few guards milled around in there, some looking underneath the beds, and others investigating the chimney.

“HEY, CLANKERS!” he shouted. He didn’t quite know where the title came from, but it just seemed… right. “LOOKING FOR SOMETHING?” A few surprised faces turned his way; Ivar gave them a friendly wave.

They were coming towards the window now. Ivar performed a small loop-de-loop for his impromptu audience, letting out a shrill whoop of excitement.

“Oh, it’s you!” he exclaimed, pointing at a guard with an unloaded crossbow. “Again, thanks so much for the exit! Couldn’t have made it without ‘ya, tall-legs!” He let out a tinkling peal of laughter at the guard’s reddening face.

The king performed a few barrel rolls before hearing a chorus of clicks from the window. He looked back quickly; four loaded crossbows met his gaze.

“Oh, grizjak.” he swore.

Ivar veered his parasol around with lightning speed as four consecutive twangs echoed behind him. Three crossbow bolts sailed around him, but one struck his mount right in the ferrule.

Ivar squealed as the umbrella bucked wildly underneath him. Gods, why had he gone back? Why had he been so stupid? And what did grizjak even mean?

But all these questions went unanswered as his flight path tipped downwards. Ivar wrestled with the handle, trying to aim it towards something softer, like a bale of hay or even a pile of manure. But the gnome-king crashed directly into…

In his mind's eye, Ivar could see the arc of descent, factoring in the rate at which the parasol's momentum was faltering, windspeed, and air resistance, and made a judgement (with a probability of 98.76%) about his landing spot. There were no bales of hay this far into the city, but there was the next best thing - a thatched roof. It would be a rough landing, but not the worst possible outcome considering.

A moment before impact, the parasol gave a final lurch, bucking straight down to smash into the thatch, throwing the diminutive Ivar like a broncho. With precision aim, he vanished down the chimney of the inn. His bouncy gnomish body ricocheted down the chute. The world tumbling end over end, there were two points of light in the sooty darkness - the diminshing sunlight up above and a growing, crackling firelight below. Desperate not to burn to death in the flames below, he outstretched his hands to grab any part of the rough stone walls, yet his body bounced off each surface like a rubber ball faster than he could find purchase.

As luck would have it, this time he received the soft landing he had prayed for before. A pool of meaty broth swallowed him up. Underwater, eyes clenched shut against the near scalding water, his hands and feet pushed through the thick chunks of carrot and turnip as large as his fists. His fingers scraped against the hot sides of the iron pot.

The air was knocked out of him from the fall - he had to get to the surface soon before he drowned. With all of his diminished strength, he pushed his feet against the iron beneath him, swimming to where he hoped the surface was.

A pink gnomish head broke the surface of the communal soup cauldron placed upon the fire of the Drunken Troll Tavern. It looked up at the high sides of the pot around it. Spluttering and spitting out a mouthful of potato, it called out in its tinny, tiny voice. "In the name of the king, help!"

The broth was hearty and thick - good for eating but less so for swimming, and it was a battle to get to the edge. Using a particularly large lump of chicken as a float, Ivar reached up, managing to get one hand over the edge of the pot, and pulling up the rest of the body. Half in, half out, he paused there for a moment, bruised, battered and burnt.

The pot sat upon the crackling fire of the common room of the Drunken Troll Tavern. An old man sat sleeping before the fire, while a smattering of patrons drank, ate and chattered around the half-empty, midday tavern, all undisturbed by the quiet plop of a king falling into the communal dinner.

11144324322.content:
Ivar quickly dipped his pink-tufted head below the lip of the cauldron, tiny eyes wide. The sense of barbaric zeal from his warrior days was still present, but the tattoo beat of his gnomish heart urged him — far more convincingly — to stay quiet.

He risked another peek, eyes scanning the room quickly. The folk ambling about varied in their respective activities — ruddy youths played cards; a bearded barkeep polished glasses; and grizzled working men seemed to be swapping tales of some sort — but they all shared a similar trait: they towered over his gnomish form.

Ivar let go of the near-scorching metal and dropped down to his chicken buoy. Apprehension mixed with fear mixed with caution to muddle his thoughts and hasten his breath. Every human — gods, he wasn’t human anymore! — was a giant to him, with hands the size of his head and limbs thicker than he was wide. Would they capture him? Was a gnome even worth being captured? Gods, what if the guard had sent word out of hi? What could they, would they do if they caught him?

Ivar shivered and tried to change his thread of thought. He cast a look at the assortment of bruises turning his pea-coloured skin a glaucous blue; the only badges of his tumble down the chimney. He tentatively depressed the soft, mottled skin, a soft gasp of surprise slipping out from his lips at its texture; that of a slightly damp rubber ball.

His mind was a tornado of thoughts; objects of alarm, unfamiliar schematics, and alien sensations all caught up in its winds. He shook his head to clear it, half-wincing at how it brushed his pointed ears against the seasoned metal. First things first: escape. The rest would come later.

There was an empty table and a swinging alleyway door some distance away from the fireplace that, thankfully, no one seemed to be paying attention to. Some extant voice in his mind whispered the time it would take for him to get there: ‘Ten seconds, eight if I sprint,’ Ivar knit his small brow into a frown at the unrequested information, but quietly gave thanks.

He grabbed the lip of the cauldron that was closest to the chimney, shakily checking over his shoulder for any stew-watchers or signs of stirring from the old man. Nothing. With a quiet squeak, he hoisted his torso up, feet dangling above the broth, before they were pulled up to an uneasy perch. He delicately shuffled along the lip to face the common room.

Ivar readied himself to jump off and skedaddle. On one… two… Wait, what was that dangling out of that old man’s pocket?

He drew his face into a squint. A gold chain… wait, no. That was Tyranian gold! Ivar’s face unconsciously relaxed itself into a giddy smile, pupils dilating to overwhelm amber irides. ‘Extraordinarily ductile even compared to normal gold, it’s used to form components in the most complex magical circuits,’ helpfully filtered into his mind.

Ivar didn’t need any more convincing, however. He leaped down from his makeshift bathtub and half-staggered over to the rocking chair, dopey grin still plastered on. The man’s pocket wasn’t quite at gnome-height, but he managed to grab a loop of the chain after two short hops.

The quiet tinkle of the chain falling sent an unfamiliar prickle of warmth through the pit of Ivar’s stomach, which only intensified with the feel of cool metal on his skin. Had he possessed such wondrous treasures in his own vault, and never known it? Ivar rubbed the links against his cheek, a throaty purr rumbling in his small neck.

Now, to procure his goods. Ivar yanked on the chain like a church bell, but it pulled taut. Ivar frowned; this would not do! Bracing himself against the leg of the chair, he gave a mighty tug on the chain, sending the cheap copper watch it was attached to sailing into the air and…

The copper watch tumbled towards him, its dented, scratched surface glinting in the light, filling his mesmerized vision more and more... and more... The heavy lump of copper and components sailed straight towards his head.

Quick as a flash, Ivar raised Tanki's satchel high, stretching the brim wide. He braced himself for impact as...

The watch slipped smoothly within the satchel of holding, the lustrous gold chain in its wake coiling down and down into the oversized insides of the bag. Gotcha! crowed Ivar triumphantly.

The rocking chair gave a lurch. The chain had become taut and the man within was abruptly awoken as he was dragged belt-first from his seat and under the table by terrific force.

That was the thing with holding charms. They liked items to be in or out, but never inbetween. A mundane item caught within a holding charm aperture could be chopped in twain upon its sealing - a magic item disastrously sundered, causing damage to the container, the owner, or everybody in a 3 mile radius, depending on the power of the magic item in question. A holding charm was capable of exerting considerable force to ensure items stayed whole and complete. Alas, to the satchel, the watch and the man securely fastened to the watch appeared to be one and the same.

The man's fingernails shaved wood from the floorboards but it did nothing to slow his inexorable progress towards the satchel. Though the satchel mouth was only inches, it grew wide like a guppy as his feet slipped within it, then his legs, until his upper body bulged out of the top. He began to thrash wildly in an attempt to grab anything to hold on to, and Ivar had to duck several times as the man's fists swung his way.

As the man took a deep breath to call for help, the satchel found its chance, gulping down the gut that had become lodged. After that, the upper body and head were quick to go, just a glimpse of fear-stricken eyes vanishing down into the dark. The satchel contracted back to normal size with an almost satisfied air.

A hush fell on the tavern as the man's final cry echoed into silence. With dread, Ivar turned to the tavern. The tavern's patrons stared back in horror.

"That gnome just ate Arthur!"

A few indignant faces looked towards the sign above the bar, which displayed the small silhouette of a Halfling inside the larger silhouette of an Orc, and the words 'Do Not Eat Fellow Patrons'.

The atmosphere was turning hostile as the hulking humanoids rose from their seats all around - the barkeep grasping the business-end of a bottle, ready to swing it, the youths eagerly producing knives from their cloaks, the workmen unhooking rusty, mean-looking tools from their belts. A pimple-faced scholar, who looked far too young to be drinking, set aside his pint and his tome, flickers of green flame igniting in his palm.

"W-wait, I can explain!" shouted Ivar.

"This better be good. Go on. Explain," rumbled the barman.

Ivar took a deep breath. "Using the Seamstresses of Nul we wove corporealised nether-confluxes via a convergence loom capable of sequestering a quantum of ethereal continuum into a minor sub-demiplane enchantment entirely within this handy hesian haversack." He held up the slightly wriggling satchel. "...or a, uh, Bag of Holding."

Even Ivar knew that wasn't the explanation they were expecting. It wasn't even the explanation Ivar had been expecting. He only recognised half the words that just came out of his own mouth. He was starting to learn that Tanki had quite a big mouth on her for such a small gnome, just as capable of talking her into trouble as out of it.

The patrons were closing in with murderous intent. Knives, flames, rusty billhooks, broken bottles, and there! - a man clutching a snooker cue! There was always one in any bar brawl. Ivar leaped at him, crying "dumb grizjak, you couldn't hit me with that thing if I was your mother, which would be very easy on account of her wei-OOF."

At the moment of impact, Ivar jumped and curled into a ball. The cue was slimmer than Ivar would have liked - a bat or racquet would have been ideal- but it had the desired effect, propelling the gnome at high speed across the bar. The wall approached fast. Judge the angle. Adjust the body. He rebounded higher, struck the barkeep square in the nose, rebounded, soared high and he unfurled himself to land deftly upon the chandelier. The barkeep clutched his spurting nose, swearing.

Ivar's heart was pounding like a drum, a mad grin on his face. Sure, he smarted from head to foot, but the sense of speed, the fine control on the rebound... he hadn't had fun like that in years. With a giddy laugh, he kicked a foot against a candle, dropping it on the heads of the attackers below. "Let's see you get me up here!"

Deep in the dark, you softly whispered “Shriiatis Vexateom” while applying a little focus to the task.

Within a moment, you felt the familiar warm pulse spreading from your chest down your arms. Scant seconds later, your sword started to glow as the spell took effect. Before long the glow was enough to see by without being blinding. Now that you could see again, you shook the map off, trying to get the worst of the water off before it was totally ruined. Going to have to really renegotiate the deal with that wizard once I’m out of here you mentally grumbled. You had a torch before, but had slipped on an unseen stone and plunged into the knee deep water that filled this section of the cave soaking the torch and everything else. The old man had incorrectly deduced that the cave would be only marginally damp.

Holding your sword aloft, you tried to make heads or tails of the map and which direction you were supposed to go now. The crude drawing had been hard enough to follow before some of the ink had started to run, and you didn’t feel like getting lost down in the twisting passages beneath the ground. Deciding on one of the branches, you set off again, senses alert for whatever had been following you since you came down here. It was subtle at first: a quiet scratch here, a soft sniff there, and the barest glint of something hiding in the shadows beyond your light. When you went under and your torch went out however, you could tell it rushed to get closer to you in the sudden darkness. With your sword illuminating the area around you now, it had backed off again. Whatever it was, it was obviously tracking you, but remaining away from the light as much as it could.

You also kept an eye on the floor below in order to avoid another fall if possible. The clear water gave you fleeting glimpses of your reflection before the ripples washed it away. Your midnight black hair was mostly hidden beneath your helmet except for a stray lock that peeked out at the edge. Thick plates hid most of your curvy body, but a careful observation could give a hint of the shape that lay beneath. Your sword was practical and without much ornamentation, except for the pommel: a gemstone that swirled with an inner light, serving as a focus for your spells. You typically went without a shield on the other arm to leave your hand free to cast spells, but could summon a magical replacement if it was truly required.

Several branches and backtracks from dead ends later, you came to what had to be your destination: a large grotto in some of the deepest reaches of the cavern. Within the shimmering depths, vast deposits of crystals sprouted from the walls. Releasing the spell on your sword, you saw that the crystals indeed cast a gleaming glow of their own; something the wizard did get correct. He said he needed several of the crystals to help maintain the barrier around the city, as well as for his own experiments, and he was paying you good money to get them. Before you left, he went into a longwinded explanation about the nature of the crystals, but the only bit you remembered was that the cave was a nexus of magical energy that allowed the crystals to constantly replenish given enough time.

You hoped that the glow of the crystals would be enough to keep whatever was out there at bay. Drawing the provided rock pick from your belt, you found a cluster of easily reachable crystals and set to work. Before long, you had a double handful of the glowing crystals tucked in a pouch hanging from your waist. You turned towards the exit but stopped and swiveled back again. On the side of one of the pillars was a crystal that caught your eye; rather than the usual greens or blues of the rest, this particular cluster was shot through with a reddish hue. Nibbling on your lip for a moment, you decided to take one of those as well, but not for the wizard, you had something else in mind for that one. It proved a bit more stubborn than the others, but after pounding for what felt to be a long time, a large piece finally broke free. You stared at the almost blood colored glow for a moment before tucking it into pocket and put the pick away.

You started to say the spell to relight your sword when you heard the plop of a stone hitting the water, right next to you. Glancing up, you just managed to see a dark shape clinging to a stalactite above you; apparently the light of the crystals wasn’t enough. In a flash, the shape dropped from the rock, slamming into the spot where you had been standing a split second before, sending a wave of water in all directions. Your quick dodge had left you sprawled in the water again, and you had only barely managed to get back to your feet before the creature was on you again, slashing at you with sickle-shaped claws and trying to take your head off. Bobbing and weaving, you managed to avoid the creature’s first swipe and the subsequent follow ups, but you couldn’t seem to hit it either. The dim glow of the crystals around the chamber didn’t allow you to see much of whatever it was that was attacking you, but you managed to see that it was both scaly and shaggy at the same time, with big eyes and an even larger tooth filled mouth. The beast was quite surefooted on the rough floor, even with the layer of water churned up by the motion hiding what lay beneath. You, on the other hand, were often stumbling and barely managing to recover to avoid a lethal blow. Sparks fell from your armor as one blow came far too close for comfort, the claws scrapping across your breastplate.

Eventually, you managed to duck into a cramped crevice in the stone wall that provided nearly enough room for you to get in while still keeping the claws just out of range. It kept trying though, slamming into the stone and breaking bits free in its rush to get to you. Now with a moment to breathe, you focused again, drawing on the magic within. You weren’t just going to light up your sword this time however.

“Flarulsi Caniecto!” you shouted, screwing your eyes shut as a tremendous flash of light burst from your hand.

The beast howled in pain and reared back. Grabbing a hold of a rocky outcropping above you, you pulled yourself up. Jumping out of the crevice with a cry of “Incenticum Consilendio!” you felt a rush of energy flow into the blade before it burst into flames. The creature was just starting to recover, but it was too late. You fell atop its head, driving the point of your sword through the top of its skull, searing the meat as it penetrated. With one last gurgle, the beast collapsed into the water releasing some steam from the toothy maw before giving a final shudder and falling still.

Panting heavily, you pulled your sword free, before wiping the dark blood off on the matted fur of the corpse. You gave the sword a quick inspection, as well as the beast, but you had no idea what it was. Thankful that you had taken only minor injuries, you illuminated your sword again before heading for the surface. The smell of charred meat and the damp clung to the inside of your nose, nearly making you gag on the short trip back to the city. Once there, you explained the trouble you had encountered and was able to get some bonus funds in compensation. He thanked you for a job well done nevertheless, and was quickly at work, even before you were out the door. Patting the pocket with your earnings, you set off again for your next destination.

They were put down rather easily, but the noise attracted what seemed to be never-ending waves of zombies. They weren’t nearly as well made as the zombies that the gypsy had possessed, but there were just so many of them down here, and they seemed to be remarkably resilient: no matter how much damage you did to each, some part of them always seemed to keep moving and trying to attack you. It came as a bit of a shock when you lopped off both arms of the first, before moving onto the second, only to find your feet tangled up because of the severed arms entangling with your legs. You freed yourself just in time and had settled into the repetitive, but still harrowing, task of hacking and slashing through the undead flesh and bones that continued to press ever closer to you. Despite the strength and endurance that your body possessed, you were beginning to feel fatigue weakening your swings and slowing your reactions—sweat was flowing freely, mixing with the foul ichor that splattered from the walking corpses and matting any lose locks of your black hair to your head.

Your options to try and free yourself were limited though, too little room to use your wings and try to fly up and out, the passage behind you quickly dead ended at a cave-in, and the zombies were pouring out of the three remaining corridors. You could try to continuing cutting through the wave of rotting flesh, but you were unsure if you could keep it up without making a dire mistake that might cost you everything. You could also try falling back into the blocked passageway and see if you could find a gap that you might be able to slip through. And third, you could pull out a last ditch move that you saved in case of emergencies, and it certainly seemed like this might be one of those times. Inhaling deeply, you made your choice and acted.
124321.title: Another "simple" job

choices: The necromancer isn’t much of a concern.
The necromancer and his friends are waiting for you.
Those runes weren’t so inactive after all, you activate a magical trap.
1243213.content:
A few more swings of your blade cut down the next couple zombies, but then the blade skipped off of a bone and became wedged in the ribcage of the next undead monster. You were forced to leave it in place, jumping back to avoid a fatal strike from claw-like fingers nearly tearing your throat out. A few more hops back the passage behind you and you had opened up a little bit of space and found that the cave-in had indeed sealed the way through, maybe if you weren’t fighting off the horde, you might be able clear enough to get through, but you had no time now. Without your sword and no way out, it was time for your emergency trump card. You turned your attention inward, focusing down into your body for the little spark of magic within. Clamping down on the little bit of magic with both muscle and mind, you felt it start to blaze into life. Briefly turning your attention to the undead creatures, you saw that they continued their slow march towards you, though the pile of their fallen comrades had slowed them down slightly. The little bit of magic became a swirling tempest, barely contained within your body, but you still had to hold on, you were only going to get one shot at this so you had better not waste it. Your body and mind trembled as you tried to contain the awesome might within yourself.

The stench of the rotting flesh rolled over you and you felt their grasping hands reaching out for you, so it was finally time. Releasing your hold on the magic, you let loose with a tremendous roar and a torrent flame that slammed into the zombies. The impact knocked those closest to you back, while the heat roasted all of them. The smell of the burning rotted flesh was horrendous, but you continued to pour on the heat, making sure you got every last one. You only hoped that you wouldn’t bring the whole building down with such an outpouring of energy. As your magical reserves ran out the flame died down, leaving mounds of blackened and shattered rotted flesh behind. Now completely drained, you dropped to your knees before falling face first into the grimy floor. Too little energy remained in you for you to do much else then lay there and hope that you had gotten them all; you were in no condition to defend yourself if you missed even one.

You come to some time later, your nose filled with the stench of the burnt rotted flesh surrounding you. A puddle of putrefied and liquefied ooze had leaked across the already dirty stones and almost reached you. Your throat was still sore and it hurt to breath, but you weren’t dead, so that’s a bonus. Shakily getting to your feet, you found that you had apparently succeeded in destroying the zombies, not a single piece had moved since you fired your last attack. Dodging most of the goop, you made your way to one of the corpses, and pulled your sword free, the flesh around the cut crumbling as you did so. Your katana was blacked and scorched a bit, but had actually been protected from the worst of the inferno by the zombies. Now armed again, you listened intently for signs of anything else in the ruins, but heard nothing except for your ragged breathing and the wind mournfully wailing through the cracked and broken stones above. Satisfied that there wasn’t any further immediate danger, you cautiously move forward, and spared a glance up the hole that you made earlier. Only a pale glow leaked down through the broken fort, the sun having long dipped out of sight, in its place only a pale sliver of the moon cast its light, and this was partially obscured beyond wispy clouds that shrouded the sky.

Now that you had the chance, you could certainly try climbing out that way or clearing enough of the debris out of the way to see about getting out, but you weren’t going to give up on this job, not after everything else you had gone through. Focusing on the task at hand, you adjusted the dented and dinged plates of armor strapped around your body and wiped off some of the foul ichor that still clung to you, staining any exposed patches of midnight blue scales a noxious shade of greenish-yellow. After that proved only mildly successful you moved on, taking one of the passages that the zombies welled up from. The darkened passages further down were barely lit by half-functioning magical lamps, but they still provided enough light that you didn’t have to rely on a torch or anything else that might attract more attention. The stench of decay still lingered in the dark dank corridors, though now it was overlaid with a bit of smoke due to the flames that you expelled. You continued walking on and on, the hidden passages much larger than the surface ruin might suggest, eventually going beyond where your flames seemed to reach, though there was still no sign of further zombies or anything else lurking and waiting to attack you. After continuing down a very long passage, you came across a large door that was inscribed with magical runes. An electric tingle caused the hair on the back of your neck to stand up and made your scales itch, a sign that there was almost certainly powerful magic beyond. You had no ability to read the magical symbols across the door, but it looked like they were inactive, some of them were even smudged and broken. Pressing against the door did little, but it did budge slightly. Gritting your teeth and slamming your shoulder into the stone slowly but surely caused the portal to creep and creak open.
1243213.title: The ace up your sleeve

choices: The capital city

12432131.content:
The room beyond was cast almost entirely in darkness, similarly lit by flickering lanterns like those in the halls you came from . Machines magical, alchemical, and mundane cluttered the chamber, along with bookcases sagging under the weight of dusty and worn tomes. A number of opened coffins were scattered about as well, though fortunately their occupants were still dead and wouldn’t be bothering you. You kept your eyes shifting constantly and your sword at the ready, wary of any threat that might lie in wait, but none were forthcoming. In the center of the room, you finally came across the necromancer that was likely responsible for the undead defense you had encountered. Your new run of good fortune seemed to be paying off again though, as the unfortunate human wasn’t going to be much of a problem with his torso hollowed out. It looked like he might have been attempting a ritual or something judging from what you could make out of the gore spattered books in front of him as well as the alchemical apparatus that had been tipped over and long since emptied of their contents. His skin was dry and leathery looking hinting that it had been quite some time since whatever had happened, and the zombies and skeletons seemed to be just a leftover from when he was still alive.

After a few prods with your sword, you turned your back on the disgusting tableau and set about finishing your task. You soon found your objective – a small worn amulet that had been gifted to the client’s lover more than a decade before, prior to him running off into the mountains and vanishing – tossed into the bottom or a small chest that looked like the lock had been broken long ago. Tucking the item into a pouch on your belt, you started to make your way towards the exit, but then turned around and went back to the coffer. Reaching in, you pulled out an old and ornate looking ring that had caught your eye before. A layer of grime wiped away easily, revealing a ruby glinting atop the golden band. You weren’t normally one to take loot from every dark and dank location your travels took you, but something about this ring drew you to it, so you slipped it into a pouch as well, thinking that it might come in handy.

As you reached the door, a raspy sound came from behind you; spinning around with your blade raised, you found the room unchanged and nothing coming towards you. Dismissing the sound as just a gust of wind blowing through the forlorn ruins, you pulled the door shut behind you before retracing your route to your entry point, with little except the sound of your boots clacking on the floor to accompany you. The puddle of liquefied zombie ooze had spread and congealed in a vast coating seeping into the rough stonework. Doing your best to avoid the worst of the vileness, you dug your claws between the stones of the wall and leapt off and caught onto the jutting fragments of the floor above and manage to hoist yourself up and out of the tunnels; with that finished, exiting the ruins of the fort was a simple matter, especially since you had more room to make use of your wings above ground.

On your journey back down the mountain, you adopted a more relaxed stance, but still kept your sword in easy reach. Before reaching the town at the base of the mountain, you took a moment to rinse off in a nearby steam, thankful to finally get rid of the noxious ooze that had clung to you the whole way. The extremely cool water splashing across your scales was bracing, more than enough to dispel most of the fatigue you were feeling from the fight and using your flame breath. You arrived in town a few hours before daybreak, and went straight for the local Adventurers Guild location, which in this rather small port only consisted of a room in the back of the main tavern. The little gnome there was a bit perturbed at being awoken at that time of night, but stopped his grousing long enough to express some amazement at someone having completed that job, as well as giving you the pay for completing the task. Leaving him behind, you slipped back out onto the silent streets, and made your way to the barn behind the tavern. Finding a quiet spot in a corner, you pulled your cloak tighter around you, keeping your sword in easy reach just in case, and a dagger in your hand as an extra bit of insurance.

At first light, you were awake and ready to go. Before heading down to the port, you stopped off back inside the tavern and gave the tavern keeper some money to pay for using the barn. The old scarred orc grumbled a bit, but took the money and waved you on anyways. Down at the docks, you bought passage on a ship, even if the captain grumbled about letting someone like you on board. Soon enough, the ship was on its way, cutting through the scant waves with a salty breeze in the sails, heading for the next port and your destination.

133.content:
The town of Sturd. Not a pretty name, granted, but picturesque nonetheless, sitting as it does upon the confluence of the bonny River Lae and River Trium within the northern strathlands, where the oakwoods begin to meet the pinewoods of the highlands. It hosts a population of around 6,000 souls, not including the hundreds of small bands of trappers and hunters that come with the seasons, and who produce a good chunk of the kingdom's supply of furs and leathers.

The town is governed by Mayor Wulfred Laneig and has been for thirty years, by his father before him. He's a military man, cares more about his counting his guard than his gold, which is what you want this far north, where you start to see the fringes of orc and centaur raiding parties. Definitely not one of those soft mayors you get down in the lowlands. His eldest is Oswyn Laneig... capital educated, well-spoken and a little... fey.

You are Finn. The tannery you work for skins and processes the thousands of animals brought in every week by the trappers and hunters and farmers, from bloody hide into finished leather. It's a huge operation employing dozens of men. Not a glamorous profession by any stretch - smelly, laborious, and long hours - but the pay is good and the townsfolk respect the work you do, if only because it means they don't have to do it themselves.

The reason it pays so well is because the job is quite dangerous. Not in the way hunting is dangerous with the threat of disembowelment from bears or boars. Not because of disease either, though the work is unsanitary (With tanning you're always working with things half-rotten and doing things to them like pounding them with manure or pickling them in urine, so the risk of disease is quite high.) No, with tanning, the most dangerous aspect by far is the husks.

Husks get around and have many names. In some places they're called fleshbags, or skinsuits, or the flayed ones. Scholars call them epidermites. Here in Sturd they're called husks.

They're a parasite, essentially, a bloodsucker like a full-body leech or a tick. When not attached, they look like the empty skins of animals or humanoids. They hang from trees or lie in undergrowth for their unsuspecting prey - anything with a pulse - to stumble upon them. Some even fill themselves with air and float on the winds. Storms have been known to bring them from as far away as Nagrandia.

When they sense the hot blood of a host, the empty husk strikes, wrapping around the host and sealing them inside itself. Immediately it begins to exude a chemical that liquifies the host's own skin, which it consumes while integrating itself into their body. The host's blood becomes its blood. Its pain become the host's pain. Within just a few hours, host and husk are one, the animal trapped within its own parasitic skin, inseparable until death.

But after death? Husks are endemic in the wild. When a hunter kills a deer, there's a good chance the carcass has a husk, and they don't often die with their host. They lie in wait until the hunter comes along and sticks his knife in them, then they leap from carcass to hunter.

That's why catches are brought to the tannery to be skinned before being sent off for butchering. The hunters know not to risk their own skin. Because once a husk gets you, that's it, you can wave goodbye to your humanity. You're going to be spending the rest of your life inside the skin of a beast.

Identifying which carcasses are infested takes a keen eye. There are certain signs. If the meat is putrid but the skin is fresh, that's clearly a husk. If the meat and the skin don't match, it's a husk, though that isn't reliable. An animal with the hide of a doe fawn but the muscular bulk of a male boar is undoubtedly husked, and even hunters know not to hunt those. But the husks are crafty and will slowly remodel the body of the host to match their own design as the parasite drains the muscle and flesh, reshapes bone, until what once was a proud rutting boar is now unmistakable from an infant doe. Even adult deer have been seen to adopt them as their own, so complete is the change. Only the behaviour of the poor trapped creature gives away its true nature.

For tanners, husks are an occupational hazard to be lived with. Though you and your lads identify most of them, sooner or later they will get you, it's just a matter of time. About a third of the team are husked, mostly the older lads who've been in the job twenty-thirty years, although poor Janik got husked in his first week. They accept it, and they adapt to it, and they move on. Alas, so too do their wives, quite often. The townsfolk treat the husked tanners with respect and pity; the same dispensation isn't always afforded their families, and very few women are willing to deal with the public shame of sharing their bed with an animal.

It could be worse. Most people taken by husks are treated the same as natural-born beastmen - collared and chained faster than you can say "free slave labour". Thanks to the Guild of Tanners, that doesn't happen. As long as you pay your guild fees, you're to be afforded all the rights of a full, human citizen even if the worst happens. Anybody attempting to put a collar about the neck of a card-carrying member can expect to have the Guild come down upon their heads like the proverbial tonne of bricks.

That isn't to say people treat them the same, mind you. Even the owner of the tannery fell to it three months ago while arguing over a delivery of skins from a dairy farm. Your boss, Oskar, went from an imposing man of late-middle age to a productive young milk cow when one of the "skins" slithered off the back of the wagon and swallowed him up. Working udders and everything. He makes a show of being the fearsome man he once was but... the lads aren't afraid of him anymore. They snigger when he birches them, and make jokes behind his back - the young, un-husked ones do at least. It isn't right. It makes you angry. The husks will come for them too eventually.

You as well no doubt. You're thirty two, you've been in this business nearly twenty years, and you still have your own skin. Sooner or later your luck will run out, but you pray to the goddess each morning that it doesn't run out today. Not for your sake, for the sake of your wife and children.

There was no time for prayer this morning. You awoke late. You hurry through the early morning streets of Sturd. The sunrise glows pinkish-red through the mist rolling down the valley side. In one hand swings your lunchbox, packed by your wonderful wife, Corinna.

The familiar stench greets your nose as you enter the tannery compound, walking past the steaming pools where the skins are processed. You pull on the heavy, stained leather apron and begin your shift.

1332.content:
An apprentice comes up to you. "Some hunting party out in the yard wanting to unload."

You smell Oswyn before you even see him, the sweet, foreign perfumes he likes so much cutting through the putrid air. He greets you with a warm smile. Nobody has ever explained what the proper title and greeting for a mayor's son is, so you give him a brisk nod and a "sir."

He spreads his arms, gesturing proudly to the catch laid out before him. A heavily pregnant sow lashed by the legs to a pole, and half a dozen rabbits. "Looks like you're going to be busy today, Finn," he says with a wink.

The four men behind him mutter quietly and roll their eyes. You know them all - they're the best hunters the town has to offer, honoured to hunt with the Mayor's boy, yet this catch represents a pitiful fraction of their normal takings. The problem is that the animals are able to see, hear and smell Oswyn coming from a mile away upwind, and you suspect that none of the men have the balls to tell the mayor's son to ditch the rainbow-coloured trousers, the perfume, and the endless chattering. Oswyn is a sensitive soul, a flower that wilts all too easily in the face of criticism.

You stumble for something positive to say. "A lot of skin on the sow, sir. And I dare say the piglets will have some too."

"That's exactly what I said," Oswyn beams. "A pregnant beast must count for triple, surely. That one was mine of course." He raises and fires an imaginary bow - even now you can see his technique is all wrong. "Pew. Shot it right in the heart. Perhaps I ought to get a portrait taken of this fine occasion..." he grins, raising his boot onto the swollen stomach as if in a victory pose.

"Wait, sir, I haven't checked it yet!" Your eyes widen as you see the pig flesh crawl. You move faster than you thought possible, dragging the mayor's boy to the ground just as the husk strips away from the flesh in a floppy, liquid blob and hurls itself at him.

The hunters are good. They have their bows in their hands and arrows in the air faster than you can blink. The arrows pierce the husk and out the other side, barely slowing it. It latches onto the nearest hunter's hand and coils up around his arm and chest underneath his clothes. His screams turn to squeals as the pink flesh swallows up his head, sealing his human face within a porcine snout. The husk gives a ripple. A trickle of steaming green liquid comes from one of the nostrils. "Get it off me! It's burning my skin! Get it off!"

You climb off Oswyn and grab the man under the armpits as he collapses in pain. "Somebody help me carry him," you bellow. The other hunters grab the legs and together you race him across the tannery to the flayman's hut. You kick open the door.

Inside the air is choked with woodsmoke. The blackened walls are lit only by the light from several braziers. Several dozen empty skinsuits hang from hooks, twitching slightly in the whorls of smoke. The flayman is the man charged with the processing and treating of the husks that get brought it, turning them into usable products. In here they are smoked for weeks until their predatory intelligence is killed off and they are made docile, able to be donned and removed at will.

"The smoke will slow down the creature," you tell them.

The flayman is there in a moment. "How long has it been attached?"

"Moments."

He grabs the husk by the snout and heaves. The trapped hunter screams and struggles as though it is his own skin being pulled away, and strikes the flayman so hard it knocks him back. The other hunters pin the man's arms. The flayman tries again, and this time he manages to get some leverage. The pig face slowly, agonizingly peels back. He draws a knife and hacks it away, peels another segment, hacks it away. The human skin underneath is red raw and blistered. The flayman covers the exposed parts in a white power designed to counter the corosive green goo. The lumps of husk wriggle on the floor like worms.

The flayman knows it is a race against time - one which he ultimately loses. He succeeds in removing the skin only as far as the stomach. In the time it takes to strip the man's leather armour, the husk has joined fully with the host. As he tries to tear away the skin below the navel, human blood begins to flow. He shakes his head. "I've done all I can. He needs a physician now."

The three hunters carry the man away. "Is he going to be alright?" Oswyn asks tremulously, staring at the curly pink tail protruding from above his buttocks, which bounces with each step.

"He'll be half the man he was before," you say honestly.

"That would have been me if you hadn't pulled me out of the way. Thank you, Finn."

"Just doing my job, sir," you say. "We deal with them every day."

"Evidently," says Oswyn, staring at the racks of smoked husks in amazement. There are ones of all types - deer, wolves, sheep, even small squirrel skins and the occasional bird. The flayman cleans his blade, takes a broom and sets about sweeping up the scraps of husk and dump them in a deep barrel of water. The husk with decompose and break apart over many months, until it forms a sort of liquid flesh paste that can be spread on to wounds.

As you step out into the fresh air, the mayor's boy turns to you.
