1353.content:
"Let it lie, Jack," your father's voice says behind your shoulder.

You almost jump out of your skin, unaware as you'd been that there had been anybody else in the field with you. He limps over the broken sods of earth, grunting as he strains his tired old back to pick up the discarded tool. "You ought to be more careful with the tools, Jack. If it were to break..."

He lets it hang, his tone gentle but the meaning clear and grim. If the hoe broke, we would not have the money to buy another. The field would go unworked, less you were able to break open the hard ground with your bare hands, and both of you would starve. You hang your head in shame. "Sorry, father."

"Leave the rest of the tilling for me," he says kindly, as you know how worn and twisted his back his become from a life of toil. "I've an errand I need you to run..."

"Bring me the herb that grows in the garden of the old hag. The one who lives by the river," your father's voice comes out raspy yet you can feel kindness in it. It seems that the years that have gone by have not relented their assault on your poor man, as his crooked back could barely support him while walking.

"Herb...?"

"Yes, specifically the Cecillia herb to---" Your old man keels over suddenly, falling on the bare, cold ground, coughing violently, with short spasms in between.

"FATHER!!" You rush over to him, helping him up to his knees while he coughs up blood and bile onto your old rags. It seems that the plague that went around the outskirts of the Empire was still affecting your father greatly, no doubt due to his weakening constitution.

"Go now... my boy... it's nothing a bit of Cecillia will fix... I will tend to... the fields," your father says as he slowly picks the hoe back up, limping away from you. He had never wanted to rely on your help, and you're not sure why. It pains you to see him like this. Could this be the pride of a father...?

"Father, no!" You scream back as you are shaken out of your thoughts by a large clunk, indicating that your father has started to till the fields. "Please get some rest."

"Rest will not put food on the table, young one," he kindly, yet firmly replies. You understand that it's his steadfast character acting up again. Not even a gnarling troll rushing at him would cause him to budge. You shake your head. Why can't he just get some rest? He won't even be able to do much work during your half-day trip!

"...Fine," you reply briefly. If anything, you will ease his pain by making the journey even quicker, lest he breaks his old bones by ruffling the the hard ground. The last thing you want to do is to grieve in front of a hastily buried body tomorrow.

The trip takes a while but is quite uneventful. You have traveled this path many times with your father, encountering squirrels, sparrows, frogs, and even pixies at time. You smile as you reminisce about a time when you have went here as a kid and pointed out a pixie to your father, calling it a fairy.

Oh the foolish young boy you were back then, not knowing that fairies live exclusively near elves, while pixies near humans. It took your father all of his willpower to not smack you when you were almost sprayed from head to toe in pixie dust, just barely dodging a tragic fate thanks to your father's quick arm. He was quite springy back in the day, not the ragged old man he is right now. And now it is your turn to take care of him.

As you approach the river, you can feel a knot forming in your stomach. The old hag was never to your liking, always constantly gazing at you with her gray, dull eyes, as she gave a nearly toothless grin, save for one or two left. Something about that gaze has always perturbed you, but fortunately your father was a skilled negotiator, and would always finish his bargains quickly. You have wondered before what life would be like if your father had become a merchant. But he respected his father too much to go for a different trade than his.

As you enter the garden, the beads of sweat rolling down your forehead instantly alert you to the old crone's presence. At first, you don't spot her, but then you notice her sitting on the doorstep of her hut, with stern eyes glistening in the sunlight. Eyes that you have never seen before. You wince as you approach her, not sure how to initiate the conversation.

"Why hello there... boy! Heh heh heh...!!!" She cackles as she looks directly at you, her piercing voice seemingly shaking your entire soul. "Now why did you come here I wonder...? And all alone too! Where is your father, Sir Pretty Face?"

This is not the first time your face is brought up in a conversation and will certainly not be the last. For some reason, it seems as if your transition to adulthood is a little bit... delayed. Your eyelashes are just a bit long, your cheeks are a bit rosy, and your chin is devoid of any hair. Certainly, you have no resemblance to people of the fairer sex, but to say that you are a real man is a little bit... far fetched.

"Honored elder," you bow as you decide to at least show her some respect. After all, you have come here for a favor and it is up to her whether she would grant it. You notice, from the corner of your eye, that her crooked fingers have begun to twirl in front of her face, pleased with something. You decide that your efforts must not have been in vain.

"I have come to collect a herb called Cecillia for my honored father. As you know, it can only be collected here and after the plague..." Your voice wonders off as you think of your father.

"You needn't speak more, boy. Indeed, the herb can heal the deadly disease that has swept through this region a year ago. Yet you should know that the herb is rare and it is exceedingly hard to grow. Nobles from all around the nation visit this humble garden, offering lavish gifts and royal services for this prized possession. What use is there giving it to a boy like you...?"

"I... The... I will... give you a part of--" You begin, but your voice cuts off as if though it is a puppet that had its strings cut. If you had actually worked on the fields, toiling day in and day out, instead of wandering in your dreams and tossing various tools onto the ground, perhaps you could have actually offered a part of your harvest. But as it stands, your father and you -- your mother has already been deceased for several years -- would barely have enough to scrape by through the winter.

"How could I be such a fool...? Because of me... I... my father..."

Your legs crumple to the ground as if though made entirely out of flax. Tears stream down your face, wetting your lips as they pass by.

"Please...!!! Is there anything I could do?! I would be willing to do anything!!!" Your voice chokes as you beg the elderly lady. Your mind wanders to your father. To your kind, loving, and caring father. How could all of this happen...?

"Boy..." You hear the old woman's voice resound nearby, as if though it is a soft melody. Perplexed by this sudden change of tone, you look upwards, gazing at her face. Her eyes and expression now look incredibly gentle, to the point where you almost think that a completely separate person has wandered in by accident.

"Boy, are you sure you have come alone?" She inquires softly, as her eyes wander around the area, seemingly looking for intruders. You don't say anything, simply nodding in response.

"I suppose then..." She begins, and a sudden flash occurs, blinding your eyes for a few moments until your eyelids cover them completely. When they open, you check the ground to make sure that your jaw hasn't touched it yet. Standing in front of you is a beauty of unimaginable proportions. Her plump lips, her deep blue eyes, her fair skin , her long red hair, her narrow waist, her wide and child-bearing hips, her long legs, and her sizeable breasts all screamed 'You would die for sex with her' to you. Yet she does not look like a typical wanton slut that you can easily find wandering around at the market, this woman simply radiated beauty, and it would not be a far call to call her the 'fairest of the land'.

"Ho ho! I suppose you have never seen a witch before, boy?"

"Huh... What.. But..." You try to utter something meaningful, but only a gurgle of unintelligible words come out of your mouth.

"Lost for words, I see. Do not worry, I will wait for you to collect the shattered pieces of your semblance."

"Are... are you going to eat me? Boil me in stew? Imprison me in a dungeon and and torture me? Drain me of all my life force through sex?" You spout, terrified of her, though your last idea does give you a little warmth. If you have to die, you might as well die in the burning flames of passion. The witch seems to see through you, however.

"Bah! What are you saying? I do not even like men. Though with such a pretty face like yourself..." She trails off as she begins to mumble something to herself. All you could catch is 'potential', 'can be fixed', 'rearrange a little', and 'as a girl', which seems like nonsense to you.

"Alright! If you want the Cecillia herb, I suppose..."

"'Maid'?" you gasp.

"Manservant. Minion. Drudge. Whatever you want to call it," the witch scoffs. "If you work for me for a year - and do a good job mind! - I'll give you the Cecillia your father needs."

You consider it gravely, glancing back at the gates of the garden as you do. As a petty serf, you were raised to have a deep respect for the contracts of bondage that dictate your life, along with a healthy any who might seek to exploit you further. The farm would still need tending, your land lord would still expect his share come harvest season. Yet you have little option, as always is your lot in life. Without the herb, it is certain your father will not live many more winters.

As you turn back, the beauty is gone, shrivelled up again into the hooked-nose crone, warts and all. Unable to contain your disappointment, you exclaim, "Why are you old again? There's nobody here but us."

The hag cackles. "Pah! Such is the way of youth. It fritters away when you're not looking! And your father is not the only one who has use of Cecelia," she says with a secretive glint in her cloudy eye. "Though I may be a thousand years old, with the herb I can be beautiful again, but only for a short time. It must be used wisely and sparingly, not to titillate some ragged farm boy!"

So that is why she hoards it so fiercely, you think. She turns and hobbles away up the garden path towards her cottage, barking back over her shoulder, "Well, boy, do you accept my offer?"

You say honestly, "I have other duties on the farm during the day. But I will work every evening, and I promise to put in a full day's work during that time."

"Pah! Promises, promises..." the hag grumbles under breath. "You are lucky you're pretty, offering a deal like that. I accept. Twelve months a slave, then you shall claim your prize, assuming you live that long!"

As you follow her into the cottage, you are shocked to discover the inside to be far vaster than the outside would suggest. Even more shocking, the place is a complete tip. Teetering piles of filthy cutlery, plates, pots and pans rise to the cavernous like trees swaying in the breeze.The witch seats herself on a mound of dirty laundry, waving her hand at the mess.

You set to the labour without another word. The basin is dry, so you search around for a bucket. Unable to find one in the mess, you take a iron pot, fill it at the river and carry it back. It takes several trips but you fill the basin and start scrubbing away.

The hours pass slowly and as darkness falls and you are dismissed, you find you've barely made a dent in the workload. You trudge home, thoroughly exhausted and somewhat demoralised. Far worse is the look of disappointment on your father's face when you return empty handed. He sucks air through his teeth as you explain the arrangement to him. "A deal with a witch is a dangerous thing, but not as dangerous as breaking it," he says grimly. He sighs and shakes his head. "What's done is done... Thank you for this, Jack."

Glancing over, he sees that you're already asleep.

There are many who seek greater understanding of the world, be it intellectual or spiritual, for with knowledge comes power. The general terms for them are thaumaturge, spellcaster, or miracle-worker.

For those of the cloth, there are many gods to whom allegiance might be pledged. Through devoted worship, you may become a paragon, a physical embodiment of your god's ideal upon the mortal plane, and by giving everything in service be raised up as an angel or even herald upon death. The path of an acolyte is fraught with peril - for the agents of other gods also fight against you in the eternal battle over the souls of mortal men. May your faith be your shield.

Scorning the gods as mere ephemeral entities, druids and shaman worship the spirits of the world itself. Allies to beasts, elementals and ancestral spirits, these protectors of the wild strive to shield their lands from all who would threaten them and prove the might of the wilds to those who lock themselves behind city walls. Rewarded for their devotion with incredible powers, druids gain unparalleled shape-shifting abilities, the companionship of mighty beasts and the power to call upon elemental might.

The Royal Colleges of Magic are institutions of arcane knowledge tasked with the training and deployment of all gifted humans. It pledges allegiance to the ruler of Tryzantium and its wizards travel across the world, aiding the kingdom's armies in battle and dealing with unnatural threats. For the hardworking men and women of the Crimson Order, Yulefest is mere background noise against which their work continues unabated. For as the motto of their college goes, 'Non est pax impiis'. No peace for the wicked.

A background noise that is often unwelcome. The sound of drunken carol singing rises from the snowy streets far below to your attic study as revelers stagger home. "Humbug," you grumble, throwing closed the shutters on the window against the unbearably cheerful noise. You slink back to your desk, moving with the slow, stooped gait of a old man upon a body that looks no older than thirty years. You are Silas Zeno. You are a Crimson Order wizard. In appearance, you are of the dark-and-handsome variety, though your features have become somewhat twisted from a century of cruel sneers and your beard is long and unkempt, your robes and faded ragged with age. When angered, your eyes flicker with flames.

The embers flicker out as you sink back into your desk chair, leaving your eyes tired and red. You are burning the midnight oil tonight, shuffling through the stacks of paperwork that fill the sparse room - notes delivered from informants and other Crimson wizards, tax returns, books of genealogy, purloined letters sent between lovers and conspirators, and a thousand other scraps of information. Straightening the spectacles on your crooked nose, you lift the guest list of the queen's famous yule ball into the candlelight, muttering to yourself. "Countessa of Orrinshire, absent from the ball... short notice... Duke of Goulcrest, also declines to attend... The Duke's entourage are dismissed for the evening. Shortly after, bottles of Orrinshire wine are sent for and delivered to his household."

You rise and carry the candle across to one wall. Upon it have been pinned a hundred or so sheets of parchment, a collage of all VIPs currently within your area of the city. Each person has a sheet of parchment pinned to the wall, with a small portrait and a list of any pertinent information - their holdings, wealth or any powerful items in their possession; family, including all known bastards; allegiances; criminal activities; sexual habits and fetishes; and so on. Anybody who is anybody is here.

You pick up the pink yarn, knot the end around the Duke's thumb-tack and tie the thread around the Countessa's. The wall is a network of rainbow-coloured yarns. Pink for sexual or romantic relationships, green for debts, black for vendettas, and so on. It is your job to track them, and to know which string to pull to get the desired results.

Aside from saving the world from demonic incursion, this is the one of the most important duties assigned to the Crimson Order, particularly in times of peace. Leverage can be anything. Bribes work. They often spiral out of control however, and any self-respecting Crimson would be loath to go begging to the Golds for cash. He straightens out, filled with confidence, as he continues in a shaky, yet firm tone.

"You see... we tieflings are quite good at sensing emotions, as you... ehm... might have found it. I have spent many years roaming the nine circles of the Underworld. I have been under the employ of many people." Kaleb reaches out to pour himself another glass, looking at you for approval. You simply hand wave. He nods as he begins to fill it.

"Slave drivers, all of them!" He exclaims with a sigh, another glass disappearing into his seemingly bottomless stomach. "And hatred? Hoo, it simply pour off them by the waves. Their malice is simply incomparable to anything in this world."

He slouches in his chair, relaxing. "But you... you are different from anything I've seen, boss. Not a single speck of malice escapes you. Even when you beat me for doing something wrong, I don't feel anything coming from you. It's as if it's only an image. A front."

You quietly growl. This bastardy fool has been reading you like an open book this entire time...?! How dare he! Gaining control of the situation was quite important now. If he blabs this to one of your subordinates - Sarya, perhaps - you would be laughed at. A conniving man has been a softie underneath the whole time? No, this won't do. The Order has taught you that you must remain by your lonesome self this entire time. Do not trust anyone.

"You should know that I can conceal my emotions..." You begin, but are cut off as you notice his smile. It terrifies you. It is the smile of someone who knows that he has won, and that the sweet taste of victory is right ahead.

"I don't think so," He doesn't back down as he leans forward, seeing eye to eye with you. "I can sense the confusion and doubt right now. The truth is simple, boss. You're actually a nice guy. And I mean really nice. There ain't a single shred of hatred inside you. I honestly don't know why you had become a wizard. But all I know is that you are hiding your face under a mask right now."

"I..." You hiss, but cannot find a reply. Under a mask? Preposterous! You have been trained in the highest Order! The most prestigious! Such nonsense and foolishness is beneath you. You are... you are...

You bite your lip as you look away. How can this be...? You have been trained to handle yourself well under pressure! And yet, you break down in front of this young boy. Has your age dulled your senses this much already. Nevertheless, you roll your eyes, stretching out your arm with the glass. To put such a shameful display in front of someone... You have no choice to admit defeat to him. But only just this once.

"M..." You begin, but sigh as you realize that you shouldn't fall to such heights. Such disgust is beneath you. "Well? Get on with it, fool."

You see his eyes brighten up, as if a candle flame flickered in front of them.

"Merry Yulefest, sir" he says, the sounds of high-pitched glass reverberating through the air. You gulp down the wine, admitting that Kaleb picked out quite a good variety.

"Oh, right, boss," he intejects...

1431121223.content:
"You remember that business you sent me to investigate?"

"The rumour of the Lemarchand's Box. Of course I remember."

He grins. A parcel wrapped in colourful paper and ribbons is placed eagerly in your lap. He gives the ornate bow a tug and the whole thing unfurls to reveal an ugly woollen sweater patterned with images of a jolly Mother Yulefest.

And, nestled on top of the sweater, a small cube of intricately interlocked pieces of lacquered wood, not entirely dissimilar to the cheap puzzle boxes often found in Yulefest crackers, except one possessing rather more hellish power. It was a Lemarchand's Box, one of very few. By disassembling and reassembling it in different configurations, it is capable of opening portals to any number of hellish demiplanes.

Disbelieving you turn it over in your hands. The wood is slightly warm to the touch and perfectly smooth except for the almost imperceptible cracks where the pieces slot together. It is a beautiful piece of craftsmanship, priceless. As you hold it to your ear, a faint alien tune hums from within. As you run your fingertips over the surface, a star-shaped section rises out of its own accord, twists half a turn and sinks back in, the song growing in intensity and complexity. Such an innocuous looking device. In the hands of a competent occultist, capable of bringing forth the armies of hell.

And it's all yours.

"How did you-?"

As you tear your eyes away from the powerful device, you see Kaleb staring at you with a strange, vacant intensity, the wine glass paused half-way to his lips. His unfocused eyes blink twice as if coming around from a half-trace. "Hm?"

The realisation clicks into place. Kaleb does have a knack for choosing the good stuff. Fine wines. Old vintages. Rich flavours.

It makes sense now. You are Kaleb's vintage. Perhaps he's right, perhaps you aren't as nasty as you like to think. But you are certainly acquisitive. You'd be a poor information gatherer if you didn't enjoy gathering things. No wonder he enjoys his job so much. Every time he brings back a new piece of intel or artifact, he gets to taste your old soul overflowing with avaricious delight. For a tiefling, your wretched presence must be like ale for an alecoholic, opium for an opium fiend.

You can even sense it, now that you know what to look for. It's weak, as most positive emotions are, but there - a faint contended glow. Does he even realise he has a problem or is he concealing it? you wonder, inspecting his honest face for any hint of addiction. He looks merely like a dog happy to serve its master. Your gaze flits down to his crotch. At least he isn't that pleased to see you.

"Sir? Did I do well?"

"Of- of course. Very... very well. How in the hell did you find it?"

"Well the goblin selling it wasn't exactly subtle about it. All I had to do was find him and explain the situation to him. I apologised and told him that we all have to make sacrifices for the greater good."

You nod, understanding perfectly. "And then you drove your sword through him and stole the box! Excellent work."

"Hm? N-no, then he gave it to me. After I described all the damage the box can do if it fell into the wrong hands, he said he certainly didn't want that on his conscience and that it should be destroyed."

You stare dumbly. "The goblin... just gave you it? For free?"

"Yes. More or less. I insisted on paying him what I could for his trouble."

"But this thing is worth a kingdom. No goblin would ever trade it for so low a price."

"This one did. I suppose you can't put a price on peace of mind," he shrugs. "If you always expect the worst in people, sir, that tends to be what you get."

"Oh please. You're starting to sound like a yulefest cracker," you grumble. "He's probably sold you a fake." You rise from the chair and retrieve your spectacles from the desk. Perching them loosely on your diminished nose, you inspect the item closer for any sign of forgery.

"It's real. I know it is. He even already had a buyer lined up-"

"Pah! So he claims!"

"-some guy called OO."

"That's how they play their cons, they lie and tell you - wait, did you say the buyer was called OO?"

"Yeah. Two Ohs. Or I suppose it could be 'Oooh'? I don't know. They only communicated by letter, that's how they signed off. Apparently they were very keen."

Odd. You scratch your beard, too embroiled in contemplation to even notice its absence. The Ordanian's contact had signed off as OO. Can it be the same person? Have the Ordanians been trying to get their hands on a Lemarchand's Box, an artifact capable of summoning hell itself within the city walls?

14311212233.content:
Investigating the little trinket in your hands - a very valuable and dangerous trinket - you find no signs of forgery, despite meticulous search. It seems that Kaleb has actually done quite a fine job.

Now that you think about it, you cannot recollect a single moment where he has let you down... that is, when he isn't organizing such farcical nonsense as Yulefest celebrations. But when it comes to missions, he has always managed to somehow complete even the most difficult of them... in the most bizarre ways (asking someone to give you a Lemarchand's Box? Ridiculous!) You cannot deny that his claim of being your best agent is not unwarranted.

Kaleb breaks your concentration with a remark.

"And now for the most important thing... we have to try this out!" You hear Kaleb say, almost giggling like a maiden fawning over her royal knight. It disturbs you, in more ways than one.

"What...? Absolutely not! You should know that this is a very dangerous piece of--"

"Tada!" You glance upwards to see Kaleb holding up the woolen sweater which is adored which Yulefest imagery. "How does it look, sir? I've knitted it personally myself!"

You blink, staring at it for a couple of seconds.

"Absolutely atrocious."

You see Kaleb's ears wane, drooping on his skull as if though they have a personality of their own.

"Come on, boss," he mutters, as he thrusts the sweater towards you, causing you to flinch. "It's the Yulefest spirit to be wearing this. And I tried so hard too."

"Maybe you should have spent that time on something better--" You begin, but stop, looking down at the gadget on your hand. After all, he did somehow find and obtain this very precious and valuable device.

"Fine," you spit, wrapping your tail around the woolen sweater, yanking it out of his hands. Kaleb lets loose a brief smile, which does not go unnoticed by you. You groan, reaching for under your armpit.

"Hey, can you help me with this? I can't seem to find the nerve nodule," you say after a couple of tries. It seems that you are not that tolerant to alcohol in this skin. Either that, or you are a complete fool for designing this skin with a small nerve nodule.

"Knee-urv know duel?"

"Never mind," you respond as you throw the sweater onto yourself. It takes around twenty seconds, nearly ripping it apart twice with your sharp horns.

"I look awful," you remark, twirling and checking yourself. The sweater droops all the way to your knees, acting more as a dress than anything else.

"No, no. You look good, boss," Kaleb says, as he rubs his chin with his arm. He steps up to take a closer look at you, knocking the empty wine bottle out of the way.

"Then again, anything would look good on you," he pauses, gulping visibly. A brief look at his crotch reveals that he is not actually aroused. You almost feel insulted by it at this point. "E-especially in that body."

Another glance reveals the same result. Is he impotent or something? Or are you not attractive enough? You somewhat panic. Operating inside a brothel, your skills determine the quality of your work. If you have lost your touch, you would need to train yourself further in seductive maneuvers.

"Alright, I think I will head to bed."

"Wait, what about the cake?" Kaleb cries after you, unwrapping yet another package with a Yulefest Celebration cake. Your eyes widen as you recognize it. Holy Rosemary! It is a legendary cake, of which only ten are baked per year. How did Kaleb get his demonic hands on one...?

You bite your lip. You do not want to admit to your subordinates - since it is a weakness of yours - but you have a bit of... a sweet tooth. You gulp.

"T-tomorrow," you barely audibly mumble, eyes still cast on the marvelous specimen. You have to summon all of your willpower to begin walking to your bedroom.

"And don't forget to put it in the cooling thermopressor" You shout, pointing at it, before nearly sprinting to your bedroom. Closing the door rather loudly, you take several deep breaths.

Shedding the sweater, as well as the dress, you slump on your bed nude. Those fools with their nightgowns! Pah! They do not know what they are missing out on. Tomorrow is going to be a long day. You must spy after General Volkov, find out the mystery of this 'OO', and decipher the various configurations ofthe Lemarchand's Box. Oh, and get a bite out of the cake too. You drift to sleep.

You wake with a numbing pain in your skull, as if though it is being split apart form the inside. Too much wine yesterday, you think. You sit up on your bed, rubbing your palm against your forehead. Alright, time to--

Your thoughts are cut off by a shriek that escapes your lips, as you notice...

143112122331.content:
A shriek escapes your lips as you notice blood pooling between your thighs. The whole bed is splattered with blood. You're sticky with it.

With a wet smack, the butchered head of a goblin lands between your legs.

Something unfurls from the roof above. It lands just as you roll out of bed, crushing it beneath its weight and turning the linen into a cloud of feathers with a blur of blades. Slowly it rises out of the wreckage. It is humanoid, vaguely. Its limbs are of black glass and fingers that end in serrated knives, all dripping with gore. Within its torso ticks intricate clockwork. The face is a polished mask, a single red crystal in the center serves for an eye.

"The box," it crackles, the voice warped and machine-like. The mechanisms inside its body tick faster as it contracts upon itself like a coiling spring.

As you seek to conjure a ball of hellfire to hand, you are made aware of a nauseating cold that fills the room, penetrating your flesh far deeper than the mid-winter air. The fire gutters out between your fingertips. Something is sapping your powers. You stare in horror at the glassy "flesh" of the golem. Obsidian, arcane's bane. A single shard enough to weaken even the strongest of magi, and this thing is made of it.

The clockwork cogs in its chest suddenly stop, then reverse. The thing lunges forward with a unbelievable speed. Your human mind freezes, powerless and paralysed. Fortunately the half-demon aspect in your muscles takes the wheel, rolling beneath its blades and rising into a sprint as the machine embeds itself in the wall.

What the hell do normal people do in this situation? What recourse do they have, besides calling for a wizard? you think, as your magic continues to fail you. Not even a simple flare spell springs from your fingertips. Oh, that's right, they die. You tear open the drawers of your desk, grabbing the Lemarchand's Box. An artifact of such power will surely not succumb to the obsidian's presence easily. If you can solve the puzzle, you can tear open a hole to hell and summon demons to your aid, or take a jaunt through an outer plane to safety-

Ten knives erupt from your chest. Their removal is far worse, tearing and ripping ragged holes in your flesh as they leave. The box drops from your limp hand. A mechanical rattle, a laugh perhaps, rings out as you thud on to the desk. Blood pours out of your mouth. You are vaguely aware of it collecting the box and departing via the window.

"Oh... oh...," you gurgle. Obsidian Order. It hurts. It hurts so much. Your pride, that is. You're an intelligence analyst; this is exactly the sort of thing you're paid to see coming.

You can't seem to move even a finger, nor have the energy to try as the life pours out of you, spreads over the desk and drips over the edge, steaming in the cold air. You try to call upon even a weak spell, a cantrip, anything. Nothing. Your magic is gone. Perhaps some part or poison of the creature remains in you. It seems you are to die a civilian, a mortal man. Less even. A naked, dead tiefling whore in a brothel. Nobody to mourn her passing. It will be the new year before your superiors note the absence of the monthly report and come to seek you out. The watch will have thrown your body in a ditch long before then.

Slowly the dark curtains are drawing about your vision. Death holds no fear for a crimson wizard. It is what comes after that terrifies them. There is a special circle of hell reserved for the souls of the wizards who have held back demonkind for millennia. An expedition even confirmed it. You can see it now - the demon in the room, come to drag your soul down to hell. Shaking you. Putting his hands all over you. Wearing a crown of brightly coloured paper. You must be delirious. Hallucinations of a dying brain. It almost seems as though it is wearing one of those stupid yulefest hats.

The demon is pouring something down your throat. Pain spreads out from your stomach, burning in your chest and skin. It drags you back, clears your head. You sit bolt upright, gasping for breath as the wounds in your chest knit themselves together, only to slump back down as the rush of energy burns out.

Kaleb is not his usual composed self. He frets over you - fear, doubt, sadness and more emanate from him. His mouth moves but you can't quite make out the words. Perhaps he is asking for orders? He disappears from view, returns a moment later to bundle you up in a blanket. You are lifted into his arms. Weak and shivery, the warmth of his body is irresistible. Huddled up against his chest, you fade in and out of awareness as he carries you downstairs and out into the snowy streets.

1431121223311.content:
The falling snow is cold to touch as your face is exposed to the chilly winds. The streets are covered in it, Kaleb's boots sinking as he begins to wade through the blizzard, shielding you from the battering snowfall. The streets are barren, all the people in their comfy little homes, celebrating the Yulefest Eve without a care in the world. A fortunate turn of events. At least there won't be anyone watching as you die a humiliating, dog's death.

Kaleb is taking you somewhere. Where - you have no idea. Frankly, it was already too late for you as the last of your blood was draining out of your system. The poison was quickly circulating within you. No magic would save you now. Anything arcane would quickly evaporate as soon as it touches your skin. And you doubted that even the most skilled physician would be able to cure the gaping holes within your stomach. And it was okay. You had already accepted your death.

The streets keep changing and changing as the puazi tiefling runs, sweat glistening in freezing temperatures, as the only thing that keeps you alive is the blanket and his warm body. You want to tell him to stop, that everything was fine, but your voice could no longer escape your weakening body. He constantly keeps glancing over at you and muttering something. What - you don't know. Your mind has already stopped hearing anything, bodily functions continuing to shut down. You hope that he doesn't overstrain himself carrying you.

Kaleb was a talented adventurer, with a bright future ahead of him. You always envied how he managed to resolve situations in the most efficient manner possible, yet also delighted as well. Embarrassingly enough, you even secretly considered him like your own son, watching the growth of his boy like any proud father would. That was how attached you became to him.

It was quite a pity, really. Kaleb had always attracted your curiosity as a member of the Crimson Order. He was quite unique even for a puazi tiefling, his generosity seemingly off the charts. He was also restrained. Whereas a regular tiefling, puazi included, would not be able to control their base desires and cravings, whether it be knowledge, anger, wealth, or love. But Kaleb... Kaleb was different. He almost seemed human... almost. You would even venture to say he was purer than most humans.

A tear escapes your eye, sliding down your cheek before it stops to rest on Kaleb's chest. You aren't sure if he felt it, but you do notice him slow down, yelling something as he pats you on the back in a comforting manner. How... soothing.

Your thoughts are thrown in disarray as Kaleb comes to a brief stop in front of a building. It was a building you knew all too well. A building that every subject in the city knew. A large cross adorned the triangular white roof, as the arches supported it along with the pure white walls. The cathedral.

You try to focus your voice, trying to warn the young tiefling. "N...no... d-don't..." is all you can moan before small body relaxes, practically crumbling in his arms. You knew that the priests didn't take kind to demons, tieflings included. You needed to warn the young adventurer, to keep him safe from peril, to protect him from death. Your death was already determined, the least you could do is to have his death bear on your conscious. None of their arts and mastery could help you, other than their holy relic, the Holy Grail. But it could only be activated once a year, a precious commodity that wouldn't be wasted on dying filth - a mere tiefling maiden.

However, your arm, your leg, your mouth - you couldn't move anything. You couldn't stop him from moving to the sacred ground. You couldn't stop him from approaching the guard, who was ready to spear him through in one blow, anger and fear clearly shown on his face. Your eyes flutter, wanting to close in order to avoid seeing him pierced through the entire length, but remain open with knowledge that closing them meant to never open them again.

You are as much surprised as the guard is to see something thrust out in front of him. It dangled from Kaleb's hand, swaying in the wind as he silently stood there. You don't know what it is, the details escaping your hazed gaze, but the effect on the guard is visible as he drops the spear and visibly scurries into the cathedral. Kaleb takes this time to press you close to his chest, rocking you up and down like a baby as he keeps muttering something. The guard finally returns with... the Archmother Helena.

You focus your concentration to the max, trying your hardest to discern their words.

"...willing to give?"

"Anything! I will..."

Before you fall unconscious into a deep slumber.

-|-|-|-


You bolt upright, the cold floor nearly freezing your naked legs as you glance around from side to side. The surrounding walls, barely discernible in the dark, do not look anything like the Ninth Circle of Hell told in legends. In fact, it looked very much like the cathedral you sparingly visited. Does that mean... that you're alive? Your tiefling hand quickly bolts to your stomach. Restored! It was completely restored, no wounds in sight!

"Kaleb!" You exclaim, glancing around excitedly in search for your assistant. But you saw no one and nothing in this barren room.

"Kaleb...?" You yell a bit louder this time, voice reverberating through the stone columns. Again, nothing. What happened to him?

You stand upright, your nude body exposed to the cold air as you begin walking to the great iron door. A quick push opens it, revealing a network of intricate hallways before you. You pick one. It doesn't matter. All of them eventually lead to the exit. You aimlessly wander around before you stumble upon a door that piques your interest as you hear the voice...

1431121223313.content:
You bolt upwards, immediately regretting the decision as a sharp pain shoots through your chest, causing you to sputter and cough up some blood. Slumping back downwards, you notice that you are lying inside a bed - one that is much smaller than the one you're used to - covered in linen sheets.

A quick glance under the sheets reveals a naked tiefling whore body, thoroughly wrapped in bandages. There's a bit of red in several places where the flow of blood is too strong, causing it to stain through the material.

I cannot believe it. How am I even alive...? I am supposed to be dead!

You wander your eyes around the room, looking for any clues. The room itself is pretty small, and humble. In fact, it seems as if though this entire room is the house. The smell of freshly cut wood and newly painted lacquer blows throughout the room. It seems that this house has been built not too long ago, possibly in the last year.

A small Yulefest tree is standing in the corner of the room, decorated with Yulefest lights and miniature Yulefest cookies. Presents are strewn all over under it, though the contents of them remain a mystery to you. A large, green Yulefest sock is nailed into the wall near a tree, filled with Yulefest candy. A smaller one is crookedly hanging there, empty, as if though it has just recently been added.

A sudden noise interrupts you as the door to the cabin is burst wide open; a cold breeze accompanying the figure of Kaleb lugging a big turkey on his shoulder.

"I wonder when boss will--" He begins, before he notices you staring at him. He instantly drops the frozen turkey on the floor with a large thud as he rushes over to you, grabbing you by the shoulders. "Boss! Boss, are you alright?"

"Stop shaking me so much, you buffoon!" You reply, feeling as if though your wounds will reopen any minute now. "And close the damn door! It's freezing outside!"

He nods, taking a few steps to close the door, before sitting on a stool beside the bed.

"How are you feeling, boss?"

"Like shit," you reply, grumbling. Not only did your body feel as if though it has been rammed by a club of some orc, your mind has also taken a toll. You have just been outwitted. You rephrase that in your head. You are an intelligence gatherer and you have just been outwitted. Those bastards. Now you understand what this 'OO' is, but you still cannot believe it. How can they betray the city...?

"Where are we anyways?" You ask, looking around. If Kaleb has just barged into some stranger's house and taken his--

"In my house. Doesn't it look nice?" He says, sweeping his arm across the room, stopping on the fireplace where the last embers are burning.

"Ah... got to add fuel to the fire," he adds, picking up some logs from beside it and tossing them nonchalantly into the fire. You stare at him intently as he does so. Finally, he returns to his seat, wiping his forehead.

"Your... house...? When did you have time to buy one?"

"I didn't, boss. I built it myself!" He puffs out his chest, looking proud.

"But you... wait a minute... so all of those missions where you suddenly go missing..." You can see his eyes shift away from yours. Got him, you think. "So you were slacking, you conniving thief!"

An audible gulp escapes his throat.

"Well, you see..." He begins, twirling his fingers and he looks downwards at the ground, avoiding your gaze. "My mother has kicked me out of the house over a year ago. 'Go find yourself a wife, you lazy bum', she said..."

He stands up, walking to the fireplace with a poker in his hand. He stabs at the pit a couple of times, peeling off the charred bark from the wood. Suddenly, he drops the poker on the ground with a sigh.

"But women these days..." He continues, downtrodden. "You know how they are. Money. Riches. Debauchery. I can't find a single honest girl these days..."

There he goes again, you think. He's always like this. Talking about honesty and traditional values. Bah! What use are they in this world?

"So... that's why you build this house?"

"Yep. Just for me and my future wife," he replies cheerfully, despite being downtrodden just a moment ago. "Although, it's Yulefest Day and I still--"

"It's what?" You shot, springing up from the bed. You wince from the pain, but don't slump back down. "I... I need to get to the Cathedral immediately. If the Obsidian Order and General Volkov meet up, then--"

"Hey," Kaleb says, planting his hands on your shoulders, pushing you downwards. "You need some rest. You were just stabbed god and devil know how many times. Recovery is a must."

"You don't understand, hellfire, demons, portals, and other monstrosity threaten the--"

"Lie down, boss," he coldly says, looking at you with an almost begging look. You do not back down.

"Lemarchand's Box! It is a very dangerous piece of equipment. The proud capital of this empire--"

"I told you to lie down, boss," he says once more. "You need rest. Let me handle this instead."

You bite your lip. What a stubborn subordinate. You should really send him back to the nine circles of hell for a while. He frets way too much over you.

"No, they have incurred my wrath. Have dare they embarrass me in such a way?! I will regain my honor in this following battle! I will show them not to mess with a wizard!"

Kaleb sighs. "You're not going to make this easy on me..."

"I would like to wish you a good night, sir," he says, as he swings his head downwards on you---

"Ow!" You yelp, as you rub your horns, as they suffered the impact. Kaleb does the same with his. "What the hell are you doing, you rapscallion?"

"Uh... sorry, boss," he replies, still clutching his own horns. "I just tried to knock you out and..."

"By... using your head, you flaming idiot?!" You yell, throwing the pillow beneath your head at him. He dodges it by a minute amount. He remains silent as he tries to think up of an answer.

"Boss..." he suddenly whispers in a low falsetto. "I cannot let you go there... It's just that..."

The husks are each the neutered remains of a parasite that seeks out and feeds on the hot blood of mortals, trapping and using them as transportation to spread their kind about the world.

Hot, living blood. It is for that reason that the skin you hold in your hands is so rare, for it does not resemble a living thing at all. The empty husk of flesh in your hands is deathly cold, palid white and damp to the touch. You unfurl it carefully. There is not much to this one, it is not particularly robust and slow to heal any tears that come upon it. Delicately, like the lover of a virgin maiden, you tease open the thin, grey lips of the face. The man is 30-something years, 5'6", wearing a dark green cotton tunic, attached by a leather belt, leather pants and boots, and have somewhat short and not quite kept black hair. Having heard what he said, the dragoness cautiously approachs the shivering man, making sure he'd see the pendant. He stutters, 'W-wait.. Y-you're the one s-supposed to h-help us..!?'. 'Yeah. So what!?'. 'S-sorry. J-just that i'm.. S-scared of you.. Y-you're a skeleton!'. She growls, 'I'm a dragoness. Not a pile of bone!'. The man meeps, 'S-sorry! E-err.. O-onyx is it?'. 'Yes.'. 'M-meet me up outside the town.. W-we'll speak of what need to do for tomorrow..'. 'Why not for today?'. 'B-because it's going to be night time and that you should rest a bit..'. The dragoness grumbles but agrees.

After meeting up where she would have more place to move, they speak up and organise what they'd do, eventually parting ways for the time being, as the dragoness places herself somewhere to rest until the sun would rise, wondering if it's a good idea to trust such a wimpy man..
1551.title: Pathway to Ferrhills.

choices: Onyx, followed by Klaus, decides to meet back with her master.
Onyx and Klaus decides to do more errands.
15511.content:
The dragoness stood there, in the outskirts of the town, patiently waiting, given she couldn't sleep anymore, eventually growling at whoever dared getting too near her belongings.
Eventually, the night let place lazily to the day, as the sun start to be visible, leaving the dragoness with a sentiment of sadness at the sight of the dawn, until she silently moves out, heading straight to the mine. Even if it was mostly used for ferrous materials, small amounts of gold and a few, albeit small, pieces of jewelry, never of great quality.

She meets up with the man that she saw last time, and given they had some time before Regef actually goes in the mine, the man tell the dragoness of some of the happenings in town:

'Regef, aware of the luxury potentially found, and being rather untrusting, regularly pays visits to the mine so he get his hands onto the valued findings. The main problems being that he visit the mine too often for what it offers, and, sometimes, remains in it for hours. Some attempts of understanding what was going on in there, albeit rare given the situation of the country, had been setted up. All failed. The most promising had been from an elf adventurer. He tried to chase the man down with one of the miners. The mine had been never heard of again, while the elf, certainly prideful of his skills, had came out insane, screaming and severely wounded.

The elf had fainted, just outside of the mine's entrance. We managed to move and to mend him, but when he woke up, he had a vicious grin, and yelled that we'd all die, before laughing in a maniacal manner. He then lunged at someone, to choke him! And despite his seemingly frail frame, he had an inhuman strength. So much we had to knock him off with a heavy log.. After that, we tied him up and left him there, trying to know what we should do. A few hours later, he had been sighted fleeing the town by some, while some others implied he went straight for the mine. All that he left was the rope that was actually holding up, torn.

Preferably, i would let you go inside alone, but then you would get lost.. S-so, i-i'll be joining you inside..'. The dragoness grumbles, 'And why would i-..'. She momentarily peer inside the cave leading to the mine. She complains, 'I can't see anything in it!'. The man ignite up a torch, before he holds it and shows it to the dragoness. She adds, 'Why you in particular.'. 'Because i know the mine, and Because i'm probably t-the only one that would help you and guide you around..'. 'Fair point..'. 'I'm Jason, by the way. N-nice to meet you, Onyx.'. '..Stay near me, Jason.'. 'O-okay..!'. Both walks into the mine.

Jason skillfully travels through the labyrinth that is the mine, at times in galleries being hand-made, sometimes leading in natural caves. Not that it stopped Onyx from complaining, 'Why is it so tight.. I can barely move..!'. The man laughs softly, 'Generally, the mine is used by humans. It wasn't meant for.. Uh.. F-for.. Powerful beings like you..!'. 'What's that supposed to mean?'. 'Nothing!'. The dragoness could tell that the human is acting strange, but she couldn't tell that Jason was actually blushing. Either way, Jason lits up another torch in the mine, making the dragoness ask, 'Why are you only igniting a part of the torches? Aren't you scared of getting up spotted?'. 'Not much of a choice.. Without light, we can't get anywhere. Besides.. If they come from behind, you have your tail, no? And if we have to flee, we can follow the trail of light..'. 'Why would i flee!?'. 'I'm no fighter, and you can hardly move.'. 'Fair point.. I hate to admit th-.. Wait, what's there?'. The dragoness points to a gallery to the left. 'There? Nothing. No minerals had been found this way, so they disregarded it.'. 'But there's *something*. Give me a torch. Place it in my maw.'. She opens her mouth up, and Jason places à lit torch in it. The dragoness adds, 'If i'm not back in ten minutes, flee.'. 'W-why?'. 'Something reeks. And i don't want to endanger you..'.

She reachs the end of the gallery and idly places a paw onto the rocky wall. Nothing seemed wrong, but corruption could be felt behind it. She starts to store up energy in her maw, when she remembers what she said. She decides to dissipate it, thankfully keeping the torch lit. And, to a fault of telling her presence, she could at least hide her breathing prowlesses. She takes a step back and swing a paw at the wall. Surprisingly, her claws went though like butter, revealing a enlightened passage.

Past it is some sort of hallway, large enough for her to move with less troubles than inside the galleries. A man stands in the end of the hallway. He speaks up, 'Another intruder!? This'll be fun! Last one was thin. But heck he packed!'. He goes into a crazed laughter. The man turns up so he faces up the dragoness. It is a noble human, 5 ft 5 inches tall, a protubering stache and a creepy grin that seemed to stretch up to its ears. When he spots the dragoness, his grin disappears, his eyes widens sensibly and he lowers his head slightly. She smirks and adds, 'Oh my. You're big! Doesn't matter!'. He draws a rapier and charges the dragoness up, grinning again.

Normally it would be child's play for the dragoness, given the human wouldn't even normally bent her bones with such a thin sword, but her instincts told her to actually be careful. The man attempt to swiftly stab the dragoness, but she dodges by jumping over him, using that moment to swing her tail at him. A heavy metallic sound could be heard soon after.
A peek at the dragoness' tail explains why: One of the blade is missing, cleanly cut. She tsks and takes a step backward after she landed up, feeling suddenly trapped.
The man cackles insanely, deviously blocking the way from where she came from. He sings, 'Breaking you will be.. So.. FUN!~'. He lowers his rapier so the tip of it touches the ground, running it on the ground with a metallic sound, obnoxiously moving slowly. As the man advances up, Onyx backs up, until a voice could be heard, 'DON'T YOU DARE!.'.

Another man appears, moving behind the noble, before he violently swings a burning torch, successfully knocking him off. Then, he kicks the rapier off, drops the torch down and rushes toward Onyx, adding, 'Oh, Onyx, you're alright..!'. 'What are you doing here!?'. 'S-sorry, but i just couldn't be helped..'. The man hugs one of the dragoness' fore leg, crying. It was Jason.

The dragoness whispers, 'Move.'. 'Why would i..'. The dragoness grits her teeth, as the man starts to wake up, 'Seriously Jason.. Move..!'. 'Wh-..?'. 'Sorry, little man.'. As the noble stands up again, and rushes at the dragoness, yelling, 'DIE!', the dragoness push Jason aside and stabs the noble, her claws piercing through his body, before he falls down, dead.

At the shock of both, the corpse stands up again, but rather than to attack, it bends backward in an inhuman angle, before a black mist pours off its mouth. Two eyes appears as a voice, seemingly coming from everywhere, speaks up, 'WHO DARED TO-..! Oh. I seeeee.~ Tell your master he'll never defeat me! Heh heh heh..'. The black mist disappears, and the corpse eventually falls down heavily onto the ground.

Rumbling sounds could be heard as dust falls down from the roof, causing Jason to scurry off to the gallery they came from. Then, he yells, 'HURRY ONYX! THE PLACE IS GONNA GET DESTROYED!'. 'But i need to-..!'. 'NOW!'. Loud crashing sounds followed by falling rocks can be heard and seen in the hallway, forcing Onyx to follow Jason. The man had taken some advance, but, thankfully, the dragoness could follow up the trail, as he said, even if it was done with unwanted charges into some of the walls.

Eventually, Onyx reachs up a natural cave in time, as the gallery she was in just crumbles away, pouring away a large cloud of dust. As the dust falls down, she notices that Jason had made it too. He says, 'Thank god. You made it too..'. 'What was *that*? 'I'm not sure.. But we should speak of it, later. Outside..'. 'Yeah..'. Both silently makes their way out, until they are outside.

They greeted by a harsh light, coming from the sun, but not fully concealing the crowd that stood around the entrance. Miners, inhabitants and guards were part of it, with more soldiers standing, somewhat away from the crowd. Whispers and voices goes in the crowd, when one of them yell, 'Monster!'. Jason rushes in front of them, extending his arms onto his sides, placing himself to protect the dragoness. 'She's with me! She was here to help us.. And she killed Regef Cinderstar!'. The soldiers that were standing besides started to back up, visibly scared, while the crowd watched them. One of the miners asks, 'What happened?'. Jason answers, 'We went it, following Regef. We found a secret gallery in it, and.. After he died, black mist poured from him. And a landslide occurred..'. 'What tells us she's not controlling you!?'. 'She's with him.'. A silent felt onto the crowd, before they yelled, against the soldiers. 'Go away! Never go in our town again!'.

All of them scurried off, except one. He's a towering human of 6 ft 2, wearing a heavy chest plate, leather skin on his chest, and leather pants. His body is pretty muscular, especially visible with his nude arms, and carries a large two-handed longsword. He smirks. 'Ugly hairface is dead? That's good.'. One of the townfolk comments, 'But he recruited you, no?'. 'Yeah. But i didn't liked him. Only joined 'cause i needed money. 'sides.. Did i harmed you?'. 'Well.. No..'. He moves up, standing in front of Onyx, 'Accept that i put my sword at your service, great bone dragoness.'. Onyx snarls, 'Call me, Onyx, ya will!?'. 'Sure would. 'Onyx'.'. The dragoness grumbles. Then Jason asks, 'Onyx..? Can you approach..?'. 'Sure..'. She executes and.. Get kissed by him! She takes a few steps off, confused. Then, the muscular man says, laughing, 'By the way, i'm Klaus 'Bearskin', lucky jewel!'. 'Shush you want!?'.
15511.title: Confrontation and friendship.

choices: Next
155111.content:
The dragoness passed the rest of the day in preparations, accepting that Klaus joins her as a group for the time being. The townfolks accepted to help her, forging specifically for her wings and legs additional pieces of armor, fitting her. They would've also offered a moneyed reward, but given that they lost a part of the mine, and due to the bad reputation that Ferrhills had gotten, thanks to Regef, they preferred to keep it to restore the town's prosperity. Instead, they offered some ferrous minerals, as well as a refined steel ingot. Onyx would've preferred Jewels over mere metals, but accepts nevertheless, feeling she could make good use of it some day, and not wanting to make them feel bad.

If she was alone, Onyx would've simply left by night, not wanting to stay for too long, as what she saw in the mine bothered her. But given she'd travel with Klaus 'Bearskin', she helped him gathering provisions for the oncoming days.
The only problem being that Onyx has no intent of lowering herself to the level of a horse by transporting anything else but her own belongings. Thankfully, one of the horses, that she scared when she met the bandits, had made its way back to Ferrhills. Attached to its saddle is two large leather bags, probably meant for transporting loot. But they were empty, aside from two bronze knifes, a small amount of money and a pair of leather gloves.

The hard part with the horse wasn't to persuade the horse to follow Klaus, nor to charge it up with the provisions, but to calm it down, so it would tolerate Onyx. After all, after trying to retain the horse, it kicked the dragoness, causing her to yell up, 'Stupid beast! Do that again and you'll never see the light of the sun again!', making Klaus laughs. Onyx then commented, 'It's going to be a long travel..'.

Onyx remained outside the town for the night, while Klaus passed the night in an inn. As the day rises up, Klaus meets back up with the dragoness, followed by the horse, soon joined up by Jason. Klaus says, 'How's the lover doing?', making Onyx growls and Jason blushes. Jason then replies, 'I'm just asking Onyx to stay..'. She says, 'I can't. I need answers.'. Jason sighs, 'If only i knew more about it..'. Onyx adds, 'You could join me.'. Klaus complains, 'But he'd slows us!'. 'I'm the one in charge, there!'. 'Tsk! Fine..'. Jason smiles, I'd want to, but i can't. I need to stay. They need my help. And to guide for the incoming investigation.'. 'Oh.. Right. Then i promise you that i will meet you again!'. Klaus smirks, 'Two little loving birds. So cute.~'. She growls again, 'Shush, you want!?'. 'We should get going, tho.'. She sighs, 'Yeah.. Let's go.. Until next time, little man!'. Jason says, 'Until next time, Onyx..'. Klaus adds, 'Toughen up, man!'. 'I-i'll try..'. He turns around and scratches his head, blushing. Onyx whispers to Klaus, 'You're an oddball.', then waves up to Jason and moves out, followed by Klaus. He whispers back, 'You're no better.'.

Once the town is out of sight, Onyx asks, 'Why did you wanted to join me?'. 'Rumors of that order. Wasn't the first time i heard of it. But i didn't believed it till yesterday.'. 'So.. If you joined me, it wasn't for what i am?'. 'Nope.'. 'Why, then?'. 'Curiosity. If beings like you are part of it..'. 'How did you knew.'. 'You have no idea of the amount of information you can get with a good beer at a tavern.'. 'You could've tempted your luck alone. I'm not forcing you.'. 'It gives me better odds to meet your master.'. 'I'm not under the rule of anyone.'. 'Heh. Even then, you are seeking him up.' 'I need answers. And help getting by..'. 'Eh?'. 'Bah. Let's say i've went through a.. Jarring transformation. Don't ask the details. I don't trust you enough for that.'. 'Oh.. Fair enough. But then, after we meet with this man, i'll decide whenever i stay with you. That's also fair, no?'. She sighs, 'Fine.. I accept. But know that he might not want to see you.'. 'Oh yeah? Why.'. 'There's more than meet the eye, about him.'. 'Heh. We meet back to him and i'll adapt then.'. 'Yeah.'.
155111.title: Back on the road

info.brief_description: Transformations in a world of medieval fantasy. Take two.
info.description:
The realm of Tamoria, home to many prosperous kingdoms, feuding fiefdoms, and warring races, where a strong swordhand, a scroll of forgotten magic, or a flask of dwarven courage may reward adventurers with riches untold, while a misstep can spell certain death or worse.

Magic is interwoven with everyday life and the arts of physical transmutation are practiced by all races. Raid a crypt and you risk triggering ancient enchantments to ravage the flesh and minds of intruders. Crossing a Goblin and his cursed blade is likely to see you become a part of his collection. Lose a fight with an Orc and expect to be reduced to a sliver of your former self, while straying into Elven woodland could forfeit your humanity.

Note from author: Since I rather wrote myself into a corner with the previous wizard-focused version, I've decided to make this one as expansive as possible. Same setting, only focusing on non-wizard folk and the other races. Once again, very few rules, feel free to be as liberal and gratuitous as you wish, and good chapters get GPs. Thanks!

Details of the lore can be found over on "Morphing and Magic" . Obviously it's a work in progress and a team effort, so by all means submit ideas for new races, monsters, and the like!
